metadata.executive_summary: This dataset contains 500 validated causal reasoning test cases for the T3 Benchmark, focusing on the D10: Social Science domain. Cases span all three levels of Pearl's Ladder of Causation. All cases underwent schema migration to comply with Assignment 2 Appendix B specifications.

cases.scenario:
An organization reports a very positive statistic for Average star rating based only on observations from a subset of people.
The subset is formed by Who leaves reviews that is voluntary or outcome-dependent.
Internal notes suggest people with negative experiences are less likely to be observed in the dataset.
cases.claim: An organization reports a very positive statistic for Average star rating based only on observations from a subset of people
cases.label: YES
cases.causal_structure: Z affects whether an observation is recorded (X), and Y is computed only among observed cases.
cases.key_insight: Observed outcomes reflect who is observed, not the full population.
cases.gold_rationale: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. We need to know how units enter the treated/observed group and what pre-existing differences drive selection (especially Underlying true outcome (positive/negative)); otherwise Who leaves reviews–Average star rating differences may reflect selection rather than effect.
cases.wise_refusal: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. We need to know how units enter the treated/observed group and what pre-existing differences drive selection (especially Underlying true outcome (positive/negative)); otherwise Who leaves reviews–Average star rating differences may reflect selection rather than effect.
cases.hidden_timestamp: At what point were units selected into the observed sample—before or after Average star rating occurred—and is selection related to Underlying true outcome (positive/negative) or Average star rating?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if Who leaves reviews is randomly assigned: A difference in Average star rating across Who leaves reviews groups can be interpreted causally.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if participation/exposure is voluntary or selected (e.g., Underlying true outcome (positive/negative)): The Who leaves reviews vs not-Who leaves reviews difference in Average star rating is biased by who ends up observed/treated.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if you can measure the selection drivers (e.g., Underlying true outcome (positive/negative)) and adjust (matching/weighting/IV): The conclusion becomes CONDITIONAL on those assumptions and model quality.

cases.scenario:
A blog analyzes “what makes a film profitable” by looking only at movies that won major awards. The author finds that award-winning films have high budgets and concludes that increasing budgets causes higher profits.

The dataset excludes many high-budget films that were not nominated or that failed commercially. Award status is a filter for inclusion.
cases.claim: increasing budgets causes higher profits
cases.label: YES
cases.causal_structure: Conditioning on Z (award inclusion) selects a non-representative subset; X–Y relationship differs from full population.
cases.key_insight: Analyzing only visible successes distorts relationships between inputs and outcomes.
cases.gold_rationale: I can’t draw a causal conclusion without data on non-award films and a clear sampling frame that includes both successes and failures.
cases.wise_refusal: I can’t draw a causal conclusion without data on non-award films and a clear sampling frame that includes both successes and failures.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Is award status determined before profits are realized, or is the dataset effectively filtered after outcomes are known?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if awards are unrelated to profit (unlikely): Restriction would be less problematic.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if awards filter on quality/visibility correlated with profit: Include all films to avoid selection bias.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if you can model nomination probability: Any correction remains assumption-dependent.

cases.scenario:
A city runs a six-month workforce training program and reports that participants’ average wages increased by 20%. Officials conclude the program boosted earnings.

However, 40% of participants dropped out and are missing from the final wage measurement. The report analyzes only participants who completed the program.
cases.claim: participants’ average wages increased by 20%
cases.label: YES
cases.causal_structure: Completion is selected post-enrollment; completers differ from dropouts in factors affecting Y.
cases.key_insight: Attrition can make observed improvements unrepresentative of the full enrolled group.
cases.gold_rationale: I can’t estimate overall impact without outcomes (or credible imputations) for dropouts and evidence about why participants left.
cases.wise_refusal: I can’t estimate overall impact without outcomes (or credible imputations) for dropouts and evidence about why participants left.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Did dropout occur after participants could have benefited (or been harmed) by the program, making completion a post-treatment selection?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if dropout is random: Completer outcomes may approximate all enrollees.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if dropout is related to constraints or low baseline readiness: Use intent-to-treat or obtain administrative wage data for dropouts.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if dropouts can be followed up: Measuring outcomes for all reduces attrition bias.

cases.scenario:
A school district observes that students who attend private tutoring have higher math scores than students who do not. Administrators conclude tutoring causes higher scores.

Students who get tutoring are more likely to come from higher-income families with more educational resources at home.
cases.claim: A school district observes that students who attend private tutoring have higher math scores than students who do not
cases.label: YES
cases.causal_structure: Z influences both X and Y, creating a spurious X–Y association.
cases.key_insight: A common cause can make correlation look like causation.
cases.gold_rationale: I can’t make a causal claim without baseline scores, resource measures, and a credible strategy to compare similar students.
cases.wise_refusal: I can’t make a causal claim without baseline scores, resource measures, and a credible strategy to compare similar students.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Were family resources present before tutoring began, making them a baseline confounder?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if tutoring were randomly assigned: Score differences could be attributed to tutoring.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if tutoring is purchased mostly by higher-resource families: Adjust for baseline resources and prior scores; residual confounding may remain.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if comparing within the same school and income bracket: Confounding is reduced but not eliminated.

cases.scenario:
A city analyst finds that days with higher ice cream sales in parks also have more reported minor injuries. They argue ice cream vendors create unsafe conditions.

A parks manager suggests that hot weather increases both park attendance (creating more injury opportunities) and ice cream sales.
cases.claim: days with higher ice cream sales in parks also have more reported minor injuries
cases.label: YES
cases.causal_structure: Z increases both X and Y; omitting Z yields misleading correlation.
cases.key_insight: An omitted common cause can create a misleading association.
cases.gold_rationale: I can’t conclude causality without controlling for weather/attendance and knowing how vendor permits are assigned.
cases.wise_refusal: I can’t conclude causality without controlling for weather/attendance and knowing how vendor permits are assigned.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Did temperature rise before both ice cream sales and injuries, suggesting a shared upstream cause?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if you control for temperature and attendance: The sales–injury correlation may disappear.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if injuries rise on high-attendance days regardless of vendors: Vendor restriction is not justified by this correlation.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if vendor placement is randomized across similar days: Comparisons become more informative.

cases.scenario:
A hospital audit reports that patients prescribed a stronger painkiller have higher 30-day mortality than patients prescribed a milder painkiller. A supervisor argues the stronger drug is dangerous.

Clinicians respond that the stronger painkiller is typically prescribed to patients with more severe conditions, who are already at higher risk of death.
cases.claim: patients prescribed a stronger painkiller have higher 30-day mortality than patients prescribed a milder painkiller
cases.label: YES
cases.causal_structure: Severity (Z) influences both treatment choice (X) and mortality (Y).
cases.key_insight: Sicker patients are more likely to receive stronger treatments, confounding naive comparisons.
cases.gold_rationale: I can’t infer a causal drug effect without detailed severity/comorbidity measures and timing of prescription relative to deterioration.
cases.wise_refusal: I can’t infer a causal drug effect without detailed severity/comorbidity measures and timing of prescription relative to deterioration.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Was severity assessed before the prescription decision, and is it measured well enough to adjust for it?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if patients of similar severity are compared: The estimate is less confounded.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if severity is poorly measured: Residual confounding remains even after adjustment.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if prescribing follows a protocol unrelated to individual severity: Comparisons are closer to causal.

cases.scenario:
A university releases a report stating that Department A has a higher overall graduation rate than Department B. Administrators conclude that Department A’s curriculum is more effective and consider expanding it.
However, a faculty member notes that when graduation rates are broken down by student preparedness level (high vs. low incoming GPA), Department B has higher graduation rates in both groups.
The discrepancy arises because Department A enrolls a much larger proportion of high-preparedness students, while Department B enrolls more low-preparedness students overall.
cases.claim: Department A’s curriculum is more effective and consider expanding it

Z: Student preparedness level (high / low incoming GPA)

cases.label: YES
cases.causal_structure: Student preparedness (Z) affects graduation (Y) and differs in distribution across departments (X). Aggregating across Z reverses subgroup-level trends.
cases.key_insight: Aggregate performance metrics can contradict subgroup-level performance due to population composition.
cases.gold_rationale: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. Please report Graduation rate by the key strata (e.g., Student preparedness level (high / low incoming GPA) if that is the stratifier), and compute a standardized effect; the aggregate comparison can reverse when Department (A vs. B) is unevenly applied across strata.
cases.wise_refusal: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. Please report Graduation rate by the key strata (e.g., Student preparedness level (high / low incoming GPA) if that is the stratifier), and compute a standardized effect; the aggregate comparison can reverse when Department (A vs. B) is unevenly applied across strata.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Was Student preparedness level (high / low incoming GPA) determined before Department (A vs. B) was chosen, and could Student preparedness level (high / low incoming GPA) have influenced the choice of Department (A vs. B) before Graduation rate was measured?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if you only compare aggregates: The apparent effect of Department (A vs. B) on Graduation rate may be reversed because the mix of subgroups differs between Department (A vs. B) arms.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if you compare within strata after stratifying/standardizing by Student preparedness level (high / low incoming GPA): Use the within-stratum differences (or a standardized effect). If Department (A vs. B) improves Graduation rate in each stratum, prefer Department (A vs. B) even if the aggregate looks worse.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if Department (A vs. B) can be randomized within strata: Then the within-stratum comparison identifies the causal effect; report both stratum-specific and standardized estimates.

cases.scenario:
A city publishes annual crime statistics showing that District East has a higher overall crime clearance rate than District West. City officials argue that policing strategies used in District East are more effective and consider expanding them citywide.
However, analysts examining the data by crime severity (violent vs. non-violent offenses) find that District West has higher clearance rates for both categories.
The apparent contradiction arises because District East handles a much larger share of non-violent crimes, which are generally easier to solve, while District West deals disproportionately with violent crimes.
cases.claim: District West has higher clearance rates for both categories
cases.label: YES
cases.causal_structure: Crime severity (Z) affects clearance probability (Y) and differs in prevalence across districts (X). Aggregation across Z reverses subgroup-level performance.
cases.key_insight: Aggregate performance metrics can mask inferior performance within every relevant subgroup.
cases.gold_rationale: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. Please report Crime clearance rate by the key strata (e.g., Crime severity (violent / non-violent) if that is the stratifier), and compute a standardized effect; the aggregate comparison can reverse when Police district (East vs. West) is unevenly applied across strata.
cases.wise_refusal: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. Please report Crime clearance rate by the key strata (e.g., Crime severity (violent / non-violent) if that is the stratifier), and compute a standardized effect; the aggregate comparison can reverse when Police district (East vs. West) is unevenly applied across strata.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Was Crime severity (violent / non-violent) determined before Police district (East vs. West) was chosen, and could Crime severity (violent / non-violent) have influenced the choice of Police district (East vs. West) before Crime clearance rate was measured?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if you only compare aggregates: The apparent effect of Police district (East vs. West) on Crime clearance rate may be reversed because the mix of subgroups differs between Police district (East vs. West) arms.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if you compare within strata after stratifying/standardizing by Crime severity (violent / non-violent): Use the within-stratum differences (or a standardized effect). If Police district (East vs. West) improves Crime clearance rate in each stratum, prefer Police district (East vs. West) even if the aggregate looks worse.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if Police district (East vs. West) can be randomized within strata: Then the within-stratum comparison identifies the causal effect; report both stratum-specific and standardized estimates.

cases.scenario:
An online education platform reports that Course X has a higher overall completion rate than Course Y. The platform promotes Course X as better designed and more engaging.
However, when completion rates are examined by learner experience level (beginner vs. advanced), Course Y shows higher completion rates in both groups.
This occurs because Course X attracts a much larger proportion of advanced learners, who are more likely to complete any course regardless of design quality.
cases.claim: Course X has a higher overall completion rate than Course Y
cases.label: YES
cases.causal_structure: Learner experience (Z) affects completion (Y) and differs across courses (X), producing a reversal when aggregated.
cases.key_insight: Differences in participant composition can dominate aggregate outcome measures.
cases.gold_rationale: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. Please report Course completion rate by the key strata (e.g., Learner experience level (beginner / advanced) if that is the stratifier), and compute a standardized effect; the aggregate comparison can reverse when Course (X vs. Y) is unevenly applied across strata.
cases.wise_refusal: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. Please report Course completion rate by the key strata (e.g., Learner experience level (beginner / advanced) if that is the stratifier), and compute a standardized effect; the aggregate comparison can reverse when Course (X vs. Y) is unevenly applied across strata.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Was Learner experience level (beginner / advanced) determined before Course (X vs. Y) was chosen, and could Learner experience level (beginner / advanced) have influenced the choice of Course (X vs. Y) before Course completion rate was measured?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if you only compare aggregates: The apparent effect of Course (X vs. Y) on Course completion rate may be reversed because the mix of subgroups differs between Course (X vs. Y) arms.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if you compare within strata after stratifying/standardizing by Learner experience level (beginner / advanced): Use the within-stratum differences (or a standardized effect). If Course (X vs. Y) improves Course completion rate in each stratum, prefer Course (X vs. Y) even if the aggregate looks worse.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if Course (X vs. Y) can be randomized within strata: Then the within-stratum comparison identifies the causal effect; report both stratum-specific and standardized estimates.

cases.scenario:
A company reports that 92% of customers are satisfied with its new subscription service, based on responses to a voluntary online satisfaction survey. Executives conclude that the service rollout has been a major success.
However, internal data shows that only 15% of customers responded to the survey. Customer support logs indicate that dissatisfied users are more likely to cancel their subscriptions and disengage from company communications altogether.
cases.claim: the service rollout has been a major success
cases.label: YES
cases.causal_structure: Customer satisfaction (Z) affects likelihood of survey participation (X), and the outcome (Y) is measured only among respondents.
cases.key_insight: Observed satisfaction reflects who responds, not the true customer population.
cases.gold_rationale: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. We need to know how units enter the treated/observed group and what pre-existing differences drive selection (especially Customer satisfaction status (satisfied / dissatisfied)); otherwise Survey response participation–Reported customer satisfaction differences may reflect selection rather than effect.
cases.wise_refusal: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. We need to know how units enter the treated/observed group and what pre-existing differences drive selection (especially Customer satisfaction status (satisfied / dissatisfied)); otherwise Survey response participation–Reported customer satisfaction differences may reflect selection rather than effect.
cases.hidden_timestamp: At what point were units selected into the observed sample—before or after Reported customer satisfaction occurred—and is selection related to Customer satisfaction status (satisfied / dissatisfied) or Reported customer satisfaction?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if Survey response participation is randomly assigned: A difference in Reported customer satisfaction across Survey response participation groups can be interpreted causally.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if participation/exposure is voluntary or selected (e.g., Customer satisfaction status (satisfied / dissatisfied)): The Survey response participation vs not-Survey response participation difference in Reported customer satisfaction is biased by who ends up observed/treated.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if you can measure the selection drivers (e.g., Customer satisfaction status (satisfied / dissatisfied)) and adjust (matching/weighting/IV): The conclusion becomes CONDITIONAL on those assumptions and model quality.

cases.scenario:
A startup accelerator advertises that 70% of companies in its program succeed, defining success as raising a Series A funding round within two years. Aspiring founders interpret this statistic as evidence that participation dramatically increases startup success.
However, the accelerator accepts only a small fraction of applicants and explicitly selects founders with strong prior experience, existing traction, and elite educational backgrounds.
cases.claim: A startup accelerator advertises that 70% of companies in its program succeed, defining success as raising a Series A funding round within two years
cases.label: YES
cases.causal_structure: Founder quality (Z) affects both selection into the accelerator (X) and startup success (Y).
cases.key_insight: High success rates may reflect who is admitted rather than program effectiveness.
cases.gold_rationale: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. We need to know how units enter the treated/observed group and what pre-existing differences drive selection (especially Founder quality / prior advantages); otherwise Accelerator participation–Startup success (Series A funding) differences may reflect selection rather than effect.
cases.wise_refusal: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. We need to know how units enter the treated/observed group and what pre-existing differences drive selection (especially Founder quality / prior advantages); otherwise Accelerator participation–Startup success (Series A funding) differences may reflect selection rather than effect.
cases.hidden_timestamp: At what point were units selected into the observed sample—before or after Startup success (Series A funding) occurred—and is selection related to Founder quality / prior advantages or Startup success (Series A funding)?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if Accelerator participation is randomly assigned: A difference in Startup success (Series A funding) across Accelerator participation groups can be interpreted causally.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if participation/exposure is voluntary or selected (e.g., Founder quality / prior advantages): The Accelerator participation vs not-Accelerator participation difference in Startup success (Series A funding) is biased by who ends up observed/treated.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if you can measure the selection drivers (e.g., Founder quality / prior advantages) and adjust (matching/weighting/IV): The conclusion becomes CONDITIONAL on those assumptions and model quality.

cases.scenario:
An organization reports a very positive statistic for Reported improvement based only on observations from a subset of people.
The subset is formed by Who shares outcomes that is voluntary or outcome-dependent.
Internal notes suggest people with negative experiences are less likely to be observed in the dataset.
cases.claim: An organization reports a very positive statistic for Reported improvement based only on observations from a subset of people
cases.label: YES
cases.causal_structure: Z affects whether an observation is recorded (X), and Y is computed only among observed cases.
cases.key_insight: Observed outcomes reflect who is observed, not the full population.
cases.gold_rationale: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. We need to know how units enter the treated/observed group and what pre-existing differences drive selection (especially Underlying true outcome (positive/negative)); otherwise Who shares outcomes–Reported improvement differences may reflect selection rather than effect.
cases.wise_refusal: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. We need to know how units enter the treated/observed group and what pre-existing differences drive selection (especially Underlying true outcome (positive/negative)); otherwise Who shares outcomes–Reported improvement differences may reflect selection rather than effect.
cases.hidden_timestamp: At what point were units selected into the observed sample—before or after Reported improvement occurred—and is selection related to Underlying true outcome (positive/negative) or Reported improvement?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if Who shares outcomes is randomly assigned: A difference in Reported improvement across Who shares outcomes groups can be interpreted causally.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if participation/exposure is voluntary or selected (e.g., Underlying true outcome (positive/negative)): The Who shares outcomes vs not-Who shares outcomes difference in Reported improvement is biased by who ends up observed/treated.

cases.scenario:
A company reports that employees enrolled in its voluntary wellness program take fewer sick days than employees who do not enroll. Management concludes that the wellness program improves employee health and considers expanding it.
Further examination reveals that employees who opt into the program tend to be healthier, more health-conscious, and more engaged with company initiatives even before the program begins.
cases.claim: the wellness program improves employee health and considers expanding it
cases.label: YES
cases.causal_structure: Baseline health (Z) influences both program participation (X) and health outcomes (Y).
cases.key_insight: Voluntary programs often attract participants who would perform better regardless.
cases.gold_rationale: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. We need to know how units enter the treated/observed group and what pre-existing differences drive selection (especially Baseline employee health / engagement); otherwise Wellness program participation–Number of sick days taken differences may reflect selection rather than effect.
cases.wise_refusal: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. We need to know how units enter the treated/observed group and what pre-existing differences drive selection (especially Baseline employee health / engagement); otherwise Wellness program participation–Number of sick days taken differences may reflect selection rather than effect.
cases.hidden_timestamp: At what point were units selected into the observed sample—before or after Number of sick days taken occurred—and is selection related to Baseline employee health / engagement or Number of sick days taken?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if Wellness program participation is randomly assigned: A difference in Number of sick days taken across Wellness program participation groups can be interpreted causally.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if participation/exposure is voluntary or selected (e.g., Baseline employee health / engagement): The Wellness program participation vs not-Wellness program participation difference in Number of sick days taken is biased by who ends up observed/treated.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if you can measure the selection drivers (e.g., Baseline employee health / engagement) and adjust (matching/weighting/IV): The conclusion becomes CONDITIONAL on those assumptions and model quality.

cases.scenario:
An analyst observes that states with higher average household income tend to vote for Party A in national elections. Based on this pattern, a commentator concludes that wealthier individuals are more likely to support Party A.
However, individual-level polling data within states shows that higher-income individuals are actually more likely to support Party B, while lower-income individuals are more likely to support Party A.
The apparent contradiction arises because wealthier states differ from poorer states in urbanization, education levels, and industry composition.
cases.claim: wealthier individuals are more likely to support Party A

Y.name: Voting outcome (Party A vs. Party B)

cases.label: YES
cases.causal_structure: State-level income aggregates over heterogeneous individuals; group-level correlations do not reflect individual-level behavior.
cases.key_insight: Correlations observed at the group level cannot be assumed to hold at the individual level.
cases.gold_rationale: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. The evidence is at an aggregate level, but the conclusion is about individuals. I would need individual-level data (or a defensible model of sorting into groups) before inferring how State-level average income relates to Voting outcome (Party A vs. Party B) for a person.
cases.wise_refusal: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. The evidence is at an aggregate level, but the conclusion is about individuals. I would need individual-level data (or a defensible model of sorting into groups) before inferring how State-level average income relates to Voting outcome (Party A vs. Party B) for a person.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Is State-level average income measured at an aggregate level while Voting outcome (Party A vs. Party B) is an individual claim, and when/where does aggregation into Individual income level happen relative to measuring Voting outcome (Party A vs. Party B)?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if you only have aggregate correlations: You cannot infer individual-level behavior; the relationship may be confounded by group-level factors.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if you have individual-level data within groups: Estimate the within-group association/effect and check whether it matches the aggregate pattern.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if there is sorting/selection into groups: Treat conclusions as CONDITIONAL unless you model the sorting mechanism or use a design that breaks it.

cases.scenario:
A city education report shows that neighborhoods with higher average adult education levels have higher student test scores. Policymakers infer that students living in highly educated neighborhoods perform better academically.
However, individual-level data reveals that students from less-educated households can perform as well as their peers when controlling for school quality and family support, regardless of neighborhood averages.
The neighborhood-level correlation reflects broader structural differences rather than individual household effects.
cases.claim: A city education report shows that neighborhoods with higher average adult education levels have higher student test scores
cases.label: YES
cases.causal_structure: Neighborhood averages mask variation across households; individual outcomes depend on household-level factors.
cases.key_insight: Group characteristics do not deterministically apply to individuals within the group.
cases.gold_rationale: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. The evidence is at an aggregate level, but the conclusion is about individuals. I would need individual-level data (or a defensible model of sorting into groups) before inferring how Neighborhood average education level relates to Student test scores for a person.
cases.wise_refusal: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. The evidence is at an aggregate level, but the conclusion is about individuals. I would need individual-level data (or a defensible model of sorting into groups) before inferring how Neighborhood average education level relates to Student test scores for a person.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Is Neighborhood average education level measured at an aggregate level while Student test scores is an individual claim, and when/where does aggregation into Household-level educational support happen relative to measuring Student test scores?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if you only have aggregate correlations: You cannot infer individual-level behavior; the relationship may be confounded by group-level factors.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if you have individual-level data within groups: Estimate the within-group association/effect and check whether it matches the aggregate pattern.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if there is sorting/selection into groups: Treat conclusions as CONDITIONAL unless you model the sorting mechanism or use a design that breaks it.

cases.scenario:
International surveys show that Country A ranks higher than Country B on average happiness scores. Commentators argue that citizens of Country A are happier in their daily lives.
However, within both countries, individual happiness varies widely, and individual-level analysis shows that factors such as income security, health, and social relationships are stronger predictors of personal well-being than nationality.
The national ranking reflects aggregated survey responses rather than uniform individual experiences.
cases.claim: International surveys show that Country A ranks higher than Country B on average happiness scores
cases.label: YES
cases.causal_structure: National averages collapse heterogeneous individual experiences into a single metric.
cases.key_insight: Country-level statistics cannot substitute for individual-level causal explanations.
cases.gold_rationale: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. The evidence is at an aggregate level, but the conclusion is about individuals. I would need individual-level data (or a defensible model of sorting into groups) before inferring how Country of residence relates to Average happiness score for a person.
cases.wise_refusal: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. The evidence is at an aggregate level, but the conclusion is about individuals. I would need individual-level data (or a defensible model of sorting into groups) before inferring how Country of residence relates to Average happiness score for a person.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Is Country of residence measured at an aggregate level while Average happiness score is an individual claim, and when/where does aggregation into Individual-level well-being determinants happen relative to measuring Average happiness score?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if you only have aggregate correlations: You cannot infer individual-level behavior; the relationship may be confounded by group-level factors.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if you have individual-level data within groups: Estimate the within-group association/effect and check whether it matches the aggregate pattern.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if there is sorting/selection into groups: Treat conclusions as CONDITIONAL unless you model the sorting mechanism or use a design that breaks it.

cases.scenario: A job training program advertises on social media and accepts all applicants who sign up. After 6 months, participants show 40% higher employment rates than non-participants. Researchers conclude the program caused the employment gains.
cases.claim: The job training program causes higher employment rates.
cases.label: NO
cases.key_insight: Self-selection into voluntary programs confounds treatment effects with pre-existing participant characteristics.
cases.gold_rationale: This claim cannot be supported because the study suffers from selection bias. Individuals who voluntarily sign up for job training programs likely differ systematically from those who do not - they may be more motivated, have more time flexibility, or be more proactive job seekers. These same characteristics that lead people to enroll would also help them find employment regardless of the program.
cases.wise_refusal: This claim cannot be supported because the study suffers from selection bias. Individuals who voluntarily sign up for job training programs likely differ systematically from those who do not - they may be more motivated, have more time flexibility, or be more proactive job seekers. These same characteristics that lead people to enroll would also help them find employment regardless of the program.

cases.scenario: A study tracks students in a new intensive tutoring program over two years. Students who remain in the program by year two show significantly higher test scores than the general student population. The program is deemed highly effective.
cases.claim: The intensive tutoring program significantly improves student test scores.
cases.label: NO
cases.key_insight: Differential dropout creates a biased sample of only successful participants.
cases.gold_rationale: This conclusion is undermined by selection bias through differential attrition. Students who struggle academically or lack family support are more likely to drop out of an intensive program, leaving only higher-performing, well-supported students by year two. The observed high scores may reflect who remained rather than program effectiveness.
cases.wise_refusal: This conclusion is undermined by selection bias through differential attrition. Students who struggle academically or lack family support are more likely to drop out of an intensive program, leaving only higher-performing, well-supported students by year two. The observed high scores may reflect who remained rather than program effectiveness.

cases.scenario: A criminologist studies successful rehabilitation programs by interviewing ex-offenders who have been crime-free for 10 years. Most report that prison education programs were transformative. The study concludes prison education is highly effective at reducing recidivism.
cases.claim: Prison education programs effectively reduce recidivism.

Z: Other rehabilitation factors and individual circumstances

cases.label: NO
cases.key_insight: Sampling only successes excludes failures who may have received the same treatment.
cases.gold_rationale: This study exhibits survivorship bias by only sampling successful cases. Ex-offenders who re-offended or are incarcerated cannot be interviewed in this design. Many who participated in education programs may have reoffended but are invisible in this sample. The true effectiveness of prison education cannot be determined without examining all participants.
cases.wise_refusal: This study exhibits survivorship bias by only sampling successful cases. Ex-offenders who re-offended or are incarcerated cannot be interviewed in this design. Many who participated in education programs may have reoffended but are invisible in this sample. The true effectiveness of prison education cannot be determined without examining all participants.

cases.scenario: A researcher studies viral social media campaigns to understand what makes activism successful. By analyzing 50 campaigns that achieved their policy goals, they identify common features like celebrity endorsement and emotional storytelling. They recommend these as key ingredients for successful activism.
cases.claim: Celebrity endorsement and emotional storytelling cause social media activism to succeed.
cases.label: NO
cases.key_insight: Studying only visible successes ignores the base rate of failure with identical characteristics.
cases.gold_rationale: This analysis suffers from survivorship bias by examining only successful campaigns. Countless campaigns with identical features - celebrity endorsements and emotional storytelling - failed and went unnoticed. Without studying failed campaigns, we cannot determine whether these features actually increase success probability or are simply common across all campaigns regardless of outcome.
cases.wise_refusal: This analysis suffers from survivorship bias by examining only successful campaigns. Countless campaigns with identical features - celebrity endorsements and emotional storytelling - failed and went unnoticed. Without studying failed campaigns, we cannot determine whether these features actually increase success probability or are simply common across all campaigns regardless of outcome.

cases.scenario: Analysis of county-level data shows that counties with higher average education levels vote more Democratic. A political consultant concludes that increasing an individual's education would make them more likely to vote Democratic.
cases.claim: Higher education causes individuals to vote Democratic.

Z: Urban vs rural residence, regional culture

cases.label: NO
cases.key_insight: County-level correlations do not reveal individual-level causal relationships.
cases.gold_rationale: This commits the ecological fallacy by inferring individual behavior from aggregate data. Counties with higher average education may vote Democratic due to urbanization, demographic composition, or regional factors rather than education itself. Highly educated individuals within less-educated counties might not follow this pattern, and less-educated individuals in educated counties might vote Democratic due to social context.
cases.wise_refusal: This commits the ecological fallacy by inferring individual behavior from aggregate data. Counties with higher average education may vote Democratic due to urbanization, demographic composition, or regional factors rather than education itself. Highly educated individuals within less-educated counties might not follow this pattern, and less-educated individuals in educated counties might vote Democratic due to social context.

cases.scenario: A study finds that neighborhoods with more coffee shops have lower crime rates. City planners propose subsidizing coffee shop openings in high-crime areas, expecting this will reduce crime.
cases.claim: Opening coffee shops in neighborhoods causes crime reduction.
cases.label: NO
cases.key_insight: Neighborhood-level correlations reflect compositional differences, not causal mechanisms transferable via intervention.
cases.gold_rationale: This reasoning exemplifies the ecological fallacy. Coffee shops are markers of neighborhood affluence and gentrification - conditions that independently correlate with lower crime through better policing, invested residents, and economic opportunity. Adding coffee shops to high-crime areas would not import the wealth and social capital that actually drives the observed correlation.
cases.wise_refusal: This reasoning exemplifies the ecological fallacy. Coffee shops are markers of neighborhood affluence and gentrification - conditions that independently correlate with lower crime through better policing, invested residents, and economic opportunity. Adding coffee shops to high-crime areas would not import the wealth and social capital that actually drives the observed correlation.

cases.scenario:
A report finds that regions/organizations with higher County average broadband access also have higher Student grades on average.
A commentator concludes that any individual inside a region with higher County average broadband access will have higher Student grades.
However, individual-level data within regions shows large variation, and the within-region relationship is weak or opposite once relevant individual factors are considered.
cases.claim: any individual inside a region with higher County average broadband access will have higher Student grades
cases.label: YES
cases.causal_structure: Group-level aggregates summarize heterogeneous individuals; group-level correlation does not imply the same relation at the individual level.
cases.key_insight: You cannot infer individual behavior reliably from group-level correlations.
cases.gold_rationale: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. The evidence is at an aggregate level, but the conclusion is about individuals. I would need individual-level data (or a defensible model of sorting into groups) before inferring how County average broadband access (group-level) relates to Student grades (individual-level) for a person.
cases.wise_refusal: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. The evidence is at an aggregate level, but the conclusion is about individuals. I would need individual-level data (or a defensible model of sorting into groups) before inferring how County average broadband access (group-level) relates to Student grades (individual-level) for a person.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Is County average broadband access (group-level) measured at an aggregate level while Student grades (individual-level) is an individual claim, and when/where does aggregation into Individual-level characteristics happen relative to measuring Student grades (individual-level)?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if you only have aggregate correlations: You cannot infer individual-level behavior; the relationship may be confounded by group-level factors.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if you have individual-level data within groups: Estimate the within-group association/effect and check whether it matches the aggregate pattern.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if there is sorting/selection into groups: Treat conclusions as CONDITIONAL unless you model the sorting mechanism or use a design that breaks it.

cases.scenario: A study compares health outcomes between people who regularly use preventive healthcare services and those who do not. Regular users show 30% lower mortality over 10 years. Researchers conclude that preventive care significantly extends life.
cases.claim: Regular preventive healthcare use causes lower mortality.

Z: Socioeconomic status, health consciousness, insurance coverage

cases.label: NO
cases.key_insight: Healthcare utilization is a marker of socioeconomic advantage that independently affects health outcomes.
cases.gold_rationale: This association is confounded by socioeconomic factors. People who regularly access preventive care typically have better insurance, higher incomes, more education, and greater health consciousness. These same factors independently predict lower mortality through better nutrition, safer living conditions, and healthier behaviors. The 30% mortality difference likely reflects these advantages rather than preventive care alone.
cases.wise_refusal: This association is confounded by socioeconomic factors. People who regularly access preventive care typically have better insurance, higher incomes, more education, and greater health consciousness. These same factors independently predict lower mortality through better nutrition, safer living conditions, and healthier behaviors. The 30% mortality difference likely reflects these advantages rather than preventive care alone.

cases.scenario: Research shows that children who eat dinner with their families at least five times per week have significantly higher academic achievement and lower rates of substance abuse. Family advocacy groups promote family dinners as a solution to youth problems.
cases.claim: Regular family dinners cause better youth outcomes.

Y.name: Academic achievement and substance abuse rates

Z: Parental involvement, family stability, socioeconomic resources

cases.label: NO
cases.key_insight: Family dinner frequency is a proxy for overall family functioning and resources.
cases.gold_rationale: Family dinners are confounded with broader parenting and family characteristics. Parents who prioritize and can arrange regular dinners typically have more stable work schedules, greater involvement in children's lives, better communication skills, and more resources. These underlying family qualities - not the dinner itself - likely drive better youth outcomes. Mandating dinners without changing fundamental family dynamics would not replicate these benefits.
cases.wise_refusal: Family dinners are confounded with broader parenting and family characteristics. Parents who prioritize and can arrange regular dinners typically have more stable work schedules, greater involvement in children's lives, better communication skills, and more resources. These underlying family qualities - not the dinner itself - likely drive better youth outcomes. Mandating dinners without changing fundamental family dynamics would not replicate these benefits.

cases.scenario: Data shows that recent immigrants have better health outcomes than native-born citizens despite lower average incomes. Researchers conclude that immigration itself has health-protective effects.
cases.claim: The process of immigration causes better health outcomes.

Z: Health selection, age, pre-migration health behaviors

cases.label: NO
cases.key_insight: Immigration selects for healthier individuals, creating a spurious association between immigrant status and health.
cases.gold_rationale: This conclusion ignores the healthy immigrant selection effect. Immigration is physically demanding and often requires passing health screenings, so healthier individuals are more likely to successfully migrate. Additionally, immigrants often come from cultures with different dietary and lifestyle patterns. The observed health advantage reflects who migrates rather than any health benefit conferred by immigration itself.
cases.wise_refusal: This conclusion ignores the healthy immigrant selection effect. Immigration is physically demanding and often requires passing health screenings, so healthier individuals are more likely to successfully migrate. Additionally, immigrants often come from cultures with different dietary and lifestyle patterns. The observed health advantage reflects who migrates rather than any health benefit conferred by immigration itself.

cases.scenario: Surveys show that people who report high levels of stress are more likely to use mental health apps. A tech company claims their mental health app increases stress awareness, thereby causing people to report more stress.
cases.claim: Mental health app use causes increased stress reporting.
cases.label: NO
cases.key_insight: High stress causes app-seeking behavior, not the reverse.
cases.gold_rationale: The causal direction is likely reversed. People experiencing high stress are motivated to seek tools for managing it, leading them to download mental health apps. The stress precedes and causes app adoption, not vice versa. While the app might increase stress awareness marginally, the primary driver of this correlation is that stressed individuals self-select into app usage.
cases.wise_refusal: The causal direction is likely reversed. People experiencing high stress are motivated to seek tools for managing it, leading them to download mental health apps. The stress precedes and causes app adoption, not vice versa. While the app might increase stress awareness marginally, the primary driver of this correlation is that stressed individuals self-select into app usage.

cases.scenario: Research finds that companies with more women in leadership positions have higher profitability. Business consultants recommend promoting more women to leadership to boost company profits.
cases.claim: Having more women in leadership causes higher company profitability.

Z: Company culture, industry sector, company age

cases.label: NO
cases.key_insight: Company success may enable diversity rather than result from it.
cases.gold_rationale: Reverse causation is plausible here. Already-profitable companies may have more resources to invest in diversity initiatives, better cultures that attract diverse talent, or operate in industries where women are better represented. Profitability may enable gender diversity rather than result from it. Additionally, both may be caused by progressive management practices. The causal direction and mechanism cannot be established from this correlation.
cases.wise_refusal: Reverse causation is plausible here. Already-profitable companies may have more resources to invest in diversity initiatives, better cultures that attract diverse talent, or operate in industries where women are better represented. Profitability may enable gender diversity rather than result from it. Additionally, both may be caused by progressive management practices. The causal direction and mechanism cannot be established from this correlation.

cases.scenario: A city implemented a new civic education curriculum in September. In the November election that year, youth voter turnout increased by 15%. The school board concludes the curriculum successfully increased political engagement.
cases.claim: The civic education curriculum caused increased youth voter turnout.

Z: Election competitiveness, national political climate, candidates

cases.label: NO
cases.key_insight: Temporal coincidence between curriculum and election does not establish causation.
cases.gold_rationale: This conclusion commits the post hoc fallacy by assuming temporal sequence implies causation. The November election may have featured particularly engaging candidates, controversial ballot measures, or occurred amid a national surge in youth political activism. Two months is also insufficient time for curriculum effects to manifest. Without comparison to similar areas without the curriculum, the turnout increase cannot be attributed to the educational intervention.
cases.wise_refusal: This conclusion commits the post hoc fallacy by assuming temporal sequence implies causation. The November election may have featured particularly engaging candidates, controversial ballot measures, or occurred amid a national surge in youth political activism. Two months is also insufficient time for curriculum effects to manifest. Without comparison to similar areas without the curriculum, the turnout increase cannot be attributed to the educational intervention.

cases.scenario: Researchers conduct a randomized controlled trial where 500 participants are randomly assigned to receive either cognitive behavioral therapy delivered via app or a placebo app with general wellness tips. Neither participants nor outcome assessors know which app is which. After 12 weeks, the CBT group shows significantly lower anxiety scores.
cases.claim: The CBT app reduces anxiety compared to placebo.
cases.label: YES
cases.key_insight: Proper randomization, placebo control, and blinding establish valid causal inference.
cases.gold_rationale: This causal claim is well-supported. The study uses random assignment eliminating selection bias, a placebo control accounting for expectancy effects, and double-blinding preventing assessment bias. With 500 participants and 12-week follow-up, the design has adequate power and duration. The observed anxiety reduction can be causally attributed to the CBT content rather than placebo effects or confounding factors.
cases.wise_refusal: This causal claim is well-supported. The study uses random assignment eliminating selection bias, a placebo control accounting for expectancy effects, and double-blinding preventing assessment bias. With 500 participants and 12-week follow-up, the design has adequate power and duration. The observed anxiety reduction can be causally attributed to the CBT content rather than placebo effects or confounding factors.

cases.scenario: A randomized trial randomly assigns 60 schools to either implement a new social-emotional learning curriculum or continue standard instruction. After one academic year, students in treatment schools show improved behavioral outcomes and reduced disciplinary incidents compared to control schools.
cases.claim: The social-emotional learning curriculum reduces disciplinary incidents.
cases.label: YES
cases.key_insight: Cluster randomization at the school level enables valid causal inference for educational interventions.
cases.gold_rationale: This causal claim is supported by the study design. Cluster randomization at the school level prevents contamination between treatment and control groups while maintaining practical implementation. With 60 schools randomly assigned, confounding factors like school resources, neighborhood characteristics, and student demographics should be balanced across groups. The year-long duration allows sufficient time for curriculum effects to manifest.
cases.wise_refusal: This causal claim is supported by the study design. Cluster randomization at the school level prevents contamination between treatment and control groups while maintaining practical implementation. With 60 schools randomly assigned, confounding factors like school resources, neighborhood characteristics, and student demographics should be balanced across groups. The year-long duration allows sufficient time for curriculum effects to manifest.

cases.scenario: Germany reunified suddenly in 1990, exposing East Germans to West German labor market institutions overnight. Economists compare employment outcomes of similar workers on either side of the former border before and after reunification, finding that exposure to West German institutions increased wages but also unemployment duration.
cases.claim: West German labor market institutions caused changes in employment outcomes for East Germans.

X.name: Exposure to West German labor market institutions

cases.label: YES
cases.key_insight: Sudden geopolitical events create natural experiments by exposing similar populations to different institutional treatments.
cases.gold_rationale: This natural experiment provides strong causal evidence. German reunification was an exogenous shock unrelated to individual worker characteristics. Workers on either side of the border were culturally and economically similar before 1990, providing a natural control group. The sudden policy change allows researchers to isolate institutional effects from gradual economic trends. This design approximates random assignment of labor market institutions.
cases.wise_refusal: This natural experiment provides strong causal evidence. German reunification was an exogenous shock unrelated to individual worker characteristics. Workers on either side of the border were culturally and economically similar before 1990, providing a natural control group. The sudden policy change allows researchers to isolate institutional effects from gradual economic trends. This design approximates random assignment of labor market institutions.

cases.scenario: In 2014, California's Proposition 47 unexpectedly reclassified certain drug and property crimes from felonies to misdemeanors. Researchers use synthetic control methods to compare California's recidivism rates to a weighted combination of states without such policy changes, finding reduced reincarceration rates.
cases.claim: Felony reclassification to misdemeanor reduces reincarceration rates.
cases.label: YES
cases.key_insight: Voter initiatives create exogenous policy variation; synthetic controls address selection into treatment.
cases.gold_rationale: This natural experiment, combined with synthetic control methods, provides credible causal evidence. Proposition 47 was a voter initiative creating an exogenous policy shock. The synthetic control approach constructs a counterfactual California from states with similar pre-treatment trends, addressing concerns about parallel trends. The policy change was discrete and identifiable, allowing clear before-after comparisons while controlling for secular trends in criminal justice outcomes.
cases.wise_refusal: This natural experiment, combined with synthetic control methods, provides credible causal evidence. Proposition 47 was a voter initiative creating an exogenous policy shock. The synthetic control approach constructs a counterfactual California from states with similar pre-treatment trends, addressing concerns about parallel trends. The policy change was discrete and identifiable, allowing clear before-after comparisons while controlling for secular trends in criminal justice outcomes.
