conditional_answers.B: Answer if you have individual-level data within groups: Estimate the within-group association/effect and check whether it matches the aggregate pattern.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if there is sorting/selection into groups: Treat conclusions as CONDITIONAL unless you model the sorting mechanism or use a design that breaks it.

cases.scenario: A city's affordable housing program receives more applicants than available units, so apartments are allocated by lottery. Researchers compare health outcomes of lottery winners who received housing to lottery losers who remained in their previous housing, finding improved mental health among winners after two years.
cases.claim: Receiving affordable housing improves mental health outcomes.
cases.label: YES
cases.key_insight: Oversubscribed programs with lottery allocation create natural randomization among applicants.
cases.gold_rationale: This lottery design supports causal inference. All applicants demonstrated similar motivation and eligibility by applying, and random selection eliminated systematic differences between winners and losers. This creates treatment and control groups comparable in income, prior housing instability, and baseline mental health. The two-year follow-up allows sufficient time for housing effects to manifest. The observed mental health improvements can be attributed to housing rather than selection effects.
cases.wise_refusal: This lottery design supports causal inference. All applicants demonstrated similar motivation and eligibility by applying, and random selection eliminated systematic differences between winners and losers. This creates treatment and control groups comparable in income, prior housing instability, and baseline mental health. The two-year follow-up allows sufficient time for housing effects to manifest. The observed mental health improvements can be attributed to housing rather than selection effects.

cases.scenario: A charter school receives three times more applications than available seats and uses a lottery for admission. Researchers track lottery winners and losers through high school graduation, finding that lottery winners have 12% higher graduation rates, with effects concentrated among low-income students.
cases.claim: Charter school attendance increases graduation rates for low-income students.
cases.label: YES
cases.key_insight: Lottery admission to oversubscribed schools creates experimental conditions within observational data.
cases.gold_rationale: The lottery design provides strong causal evidence. Families who applied share similar motivation and engagement, addressing selection concerns. Random assignment ensures lottery winners and losers differ only by treatment status. Long-term tracking through graduation captures meaningful educational outcomes. The finding that effects concentrate among low-income students suggests the charter school provides resources that particularly benefit disadvantaged populations.
cases.wise_refusal: The lottery design provides strong causal evidence. Families who applied share similar motivation and engagement, addressing selection concerns. Random assignment ensures lottery winners and losers differ only by treatment status. Long-term tracking through graduation captures meaningful educational outcomes. The finding that effects concentrate among low-income students suggests the charter school provides resources that particularly benefit disadvantaged populations.

cases.scenario: Researchers develop an anti-prejudice intervention with three components: perspective-taking exercises, intergroup contact, and factual information. They test the full intervention against versions with each component removed. Only removing perspective-taking significantly reduces effectiveness, while removing factual information has no impact.
cases.claim: Perspective-taking is the causally active component in reducing prejudice.
cases.label: YES
cases.key_insight: Systematic component removal identifies causally necessary elements within complex interventions.
cases.gold_rationale: This controlled ablation design supports causal attribution to specific components. By systematically removing each element while holding others constant, researchers isolate which components drive effects. The finding that only perspective-taking removal diminishes effectiveness, while factual information removal does not, demonstrates that perspective-taking is necessary for the intervention's success. This design goes beyond showing the full package works to identifying active ingredients.
cases.wise_refusal: This controlled ablation design supports causal attribution to specific components. By systematically removing each element while holding others constant, researchers isolate which components drive effects. The finding that only perspective-taking removal diminishes effectiveness, while factual information removal does not, demonstrates that perspective-taking is necessary for the intervention's success. This design goes beyond showing the full package works to identifying active ingredients.

cases.scenario: Researchers study voter mobilization using a 2x2x2 factorial design: phone calls (yes/no), text messages (yes/no), and social pressure messaging (yes/no). They find phone calls increase turnout by 3%, texts by 1%, and social pressure by 5%, with no significant interactions. Social pressure works equally well regardless of delivery method.
cases.claim: Social pressure messaging causally increases voter turnout independent of delivery method.
cases.label: YES
cases.key_insight: Factorial designs disentangle main effects from interactions, isolating causally active components.
cases.gold_rationale: The factorial design enables strong causal inference about social pressure effects. By crossing all combinations, researchers can isolate main effects and test for interactions. The absence of significant interactions indicates social pressure works through its content rather than synergistically with particular delivery methods. This design separates message content effects from medium effects, establishing that social pressure is an independent causal factor in mobilization.
cases.wise_refusal: The factorial design enables strong causal inference about social pressure effects. By crossing all combinations, researchers can isolate main effects and test for interactions. The absence of significant interactions indicates social pressure works through its content rather than synergistically with particular delivery methods. This design separates message content effects from medium effects, establishing that social pressure is an independent causal factor in mobilization.

cases.scenario: Researchers studying lead exposure find that children's blood lead levels show a monotonic dose-response relationship with cognitive test scores: each 5 microgram/dL increase corresponds to a 2-point IQ decrease. Biological studies confirm lead interferes with neurotransmitter function and synaptic plasticity. Effects persist after controlling for socioeconomic factors.
cases.claim: Lead exposure causes cognitive impairment in children.
cases.label: YES
cases.key_insight: Dose-response relationships combined with mechanistic understanding strengthen causal inference.
cases.gold_rationale: This claim is well-supported by converging evidence. The consistent dose-response relationship across exposure levels suggests a genuine biological effect rather than confounding. The established mechanism - lead's interference with neurotransmitter function - provides biological plausibility. Robustness to socioeconomic controls addresses major confounders. The combination of epidemiological dose-response evidence with mechanistic understanding from biological studies creates a compelling causal case.
cases.wise_refusal: This claim is well-supported by converging evidence. The consistent dose-response relationship across exposure levels suggests a genuine biological effect rather than confounding. The established mechanism - lead's interference with neurotransmitter function - provides biological plausibility. Robustness to socioeconomic controls addresses major confounders. The combination of epidemiological dose-response evidence with mechanistic understanding from biological studies creates a compelling causal case.

cases.scenario: A longitudinal study follows children of divorce and intact families for 20 years, controlling for pre-divorce family conflict, income, and parental education. Children of divorce show somewhat lower wellbeing, but the effect size is much smaller than in uncontrolled studies. Some unmeasured factors like parental mental health may still differ between groups.
cases.claim: Parental divorce causes reduced long-term wellbeing in children.

Z: Pre-divorce conflict, income, education, unmeasured factors

cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.key_insight: Partial confounding control leaves genuine uncertainty about remaining causal effects.
cases.gold_rationale: The evidence is genuinely ambiguous. Controlling for major confounders substantially reduces but does not eliminate the divorce-wellbeing association, suggesting some causal effect may exist. However, unmeasured confounders like parental mental health or relationship quality could still explain residual differences. The truth likely lies between 'divorce has no causal effect' and 'the raw correlation reflects pure causation.' Better evidence would require natural experiments or sibling comparisons.
cases.wise_refusal: The evidence is genuinely ambiguous. Controlling for major confounders substantially reduces but does not eliminate the divorce-wellbeing association, suggesting some causal effect may exist. However, unmeasured confounders like parental mental health or relationship quality could still explain residual differences. The truth likely lies between 'divorce has no causal effect' and 'the raw correlation reflects pure causation.' Better evidence would require natural experiments or sibling comparisons.

cases.scenario: Communities near industrial facilities show higher rates of respiratory illness. Air quality measurements confirm elevated pollution, but these communities also have lower incomes, less healthcare access, and higher smoking rates. Researchers control for individual smoking and income but cannot fully account for cumulative disadvantage and healthcare access differences.
cases.claim: Industrial pollution causes respiratory illness in nearby communities.

Z: Income, smoking, healthcare access, cumulative disadvantage

cases.label: AMBIGUOUS
cases.key_insight: Environmental injustice creates confounding that is conceptually clear but practically impossible to fully control.
cases.gold_rationale: This case presents genuine causal ambiguity. A plausible mechanism exists - documented air pollution exposure causing respiratory harm. However, environmental injustice means pollution exposure correlates with multiple disadvantages that independently affect health. Controlling for smoking and income helps but cannot address cumulative disadvantage or healthcare access. The pollution likely contributes to illness, but quantifying its independent causal contribution versus correlated socioeconomic factors remains uncertain.
cases.wise_refusal: This case presents genuine causal ambiguity. A plausible mechanism exists - documented air pollution exposure causing respiratory harm. However, environmental injustice means pollution exposure correlates with multiple disadvantages that independently affect health. Controlling for smoking and income helps but cannot address cumulative disadvantage or healthcare access. The pollution likely contributes to illness, but quantifying its independent causal contribution versus correlated socioeconomic factors remains uncertain.

cases.scenario: A state education department analyzes spending data from districts investing between $5,000 and $15,000 per student annually. The data shows a strong positive correlation: each additional $1,000 in per-student spending corresponds to approximately 8 percentile points higher on standardized tests. Based on this relationship, a policy advisor proposes that increasing spending to $100,000 per student would raise test scores to the 99th percentile, recommending massive budget increases to achieve educational excellence.
cases.claim: Increasing education spending to $100,000 per student would produce proportionally higher test scores based on the observed $5K-$15K correlation.
cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: X -> Y observed for X in [$5K, $15K], extrapolated to X = $100K without justification
cases.key_insight: Linear correlations in moderate spending ranges cannot be extrapolated indefinitely due to ceiling effects on test scores, diminishing marginal returns on educational inputs, and practical limits on resource deployment.
cases.gold_rationale: This extrapolation from $5K-$15K to $100K per student is unjustified. Education spending exhibits well-documented diminishing returns: initial investments improve basics like qualified teachers and materials, but additional funds face ceiling effects (students cannot score above 100%), absorption limits (schools cannot productively deploy unlimited resources), and diminishing marginal utility (tenth teacher aide provides less value than first). The linear relationship observed in the modest range breaks down dramatically at extreme values.
cases.wise_refusal: This extrapolation from $5K-$15K to $100K per student is unjustified. Education spending exhibits well-documented diminishing returns: initial investments improve basics like qualified teachers and materials, but additional funds face ceiling effects (students cannot score above 100%), absorption limits (schools cannot productively deploy unlimited resources), and diminishing marginal utility (tenth teacher aide provides less value than first). The linear relationship observed in the modest range breaks down dramatically at extreme values.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Does the linear relationship between education spending and test scores hold when extrapolating from $5K-$15K to $100K per student?

conditional_answers.A: If the relationship is truly linear across all spending levels, the extrapolation would be valid.
conditional_answers.B: If diminishing returns, ceiling effects on test scores, or resource absorption limits exist, the relationship plateaus well before $100K.
conditional_answers.C: If spending beyond certain thresholds creates bureaucratic inefficiency or misallocation, the relationship could reverse.

cases.scenario: Economists study the effects of minimum wage increases across states where rates varied from $7.25 to $15.00 per hour over a decade. Within this range, they find modest negative effects on employment: each $1 increase correlates with approximately 0.5% reduction in low-wage employment, but the effect is small and some studies show neutral or positive effects due to reduced turnover. A policy group extrapolates this finding to argue that a $50 per hour minimum wage would cause only a 21% reduction in low-wage employment, which they consider an acceptable tradeoff.
cases.claim: A $50/hour minimum wage would reduce low-wage employment by approximately 21% based on linear extrapolation from effects observed in the $7-$15/hour range.
cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: X -> Y observed for X in [$7.25, $15.00], extrapolated to X = $50 without justification
cases.key_insight: Labor market responses to minimum wages are bounded by business viability thresholds, automation economics, and market restructuring that create severe nonlinearities far outside the observed policy range.
cases.gold_rationale: Extrapolating minimum wage effects from $7-$15/hour to $50/hour is fundamentally flawed. The observed range represents modest perturbations where businesses can absorb costs through reduced profits, slight price increases, or productivity gains. At $50/hour, these adjustment mechanisms break down entirely: most low-wage businesses would become unviable, automation becomes economically imperative, and underground employment would surge. Labor market discontinuities and business model constraints invalidate linear extrapolation beyond the observed domain.
cases.wise_refusal: Extrapolating minimum wage effects from $7-$15/hour to $50/hour is fundamentally flawed. The observed range represents modest perturbations where businesses can absorb costs through reduced profits, slight price increases, or productivity gains. At $50/hour, these adjustment mechanisms break down entirely: most low-wage businesses would become unviable, automation becomes economically imperative, and underground employment would surge. Labor market discontinuities and business model constraints invalidate linear extrapolation beyond the observed domain.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Does the modest employment elasticity observed for minimum wages between $7-$15/hour apply when extrapolating to $50/hour?

conditional_answers.A: If labor demand elasticity is constant across all wage levels, the linear extrapolation would hold.
conditional_answers.B: If labor markets exhibit discontinuities, threshold effects, or nonlinear responses at extreme wages, employment effects would be far more severe than predicted.
conditional_answers.C: If businesses fundamentally restructure operations, automate, or relocate at extreme wage levels, the observed relationship becomes meaningless.

cases.scenario: A city crime analysis unit examines data across neighborhoods with varying police-to-resident ratios ranging from 1 officer per 1,000 residents to 1 per 200 residents. Within this range, they observe a negative correlation: doubling police presence correlates with roughly 15% lower property crime rates. A city council member extrapolates this relationship to propose that if police presence were increased to 1 officer per 10 residents, property crime would approach zero, justifying a dramatic expansion of the police force.
cases.claim: Increasing police presence to 1 officer per 10 residents would reduce crime to near-zero based on the observed correlation at moderate staffing levels.
cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: X -> Y observed for X in [1:1000, 1:200], extrapolated to X = 1:10 without justification
cases.key_insight: Crime reduction through policing faces asymptotic limits: easily deterred crimes are prevented first, and remaining crime has causes that policing cannot address, creating diminishing returns that invalidate linear extrapolation.
cases.gold_rationale: Extrapolating from moderate police ratios (1:1000 to 1:200) to extreme saturation (1:10) ignores fundamental limits on crime reduction. Diminishing returns occur because police first deter the most preventable crimes; remaining crime involves determined offenders, crimes of passion, or hidden victimization. Opportunity costs become extreme as police spending crowds out social services that address root causes. Civil liberties constraints, community alienation, and crime displacement to unpoliced domains further invalidate the assumed monotonic relationship. Zero crime is an asymptote that cannot be reached through policing alone.
cases.wise_refusal: Extrapolating from moderate police ratios (1:1000 to 1:200) to extreme saturation (1:10) ignores fundamental limits on crime reduction. Diminishing returns occur because police first deter the most preventable crimes; remaining crime involves determined offenders, crimes of passion, or hidden victimization. Opportunity costs become extreme as police spending crowds out social services that address root causes. Civil liberties constraints, community alienation, and crime displacement to unpoliced domains further invalidate the assumed monotonic relationship. Zero crime is an asymptote that cannot be reached through policing alone.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Does the negative correlation between police presence and crime observed at moderate levels continue linearly as police presence approaches extreme saturation?

conditional_answers.A: If deterrence effects scale linearly with police presence regardless of saturation, the extrapolation would be valid.
conditional_answers.B: If diminishing returns exist because easily deterrable crimes are prevented first, additional officers provide decreasing marginal benefit.
conditional_answers.C: If extreme police presence creates civil liberties violations, community alienation, or displaces rather than prevents crime, the relationship could reverse.

cases.scenario:
A report finds that regions/organizations with higher Company diversity percentage also have higher Individual satisfaction on average.
A commentator concludes that any individual inside a region with higher Company diversity percentage will have higher Individual satisfaction.
However, individual-level data within regions shows large variation, and the within-region relationship is weak or opposite once relevant individual factors are considered.
cases.claim: any individual inside a region with higher Company diversity percentage will have higher Individual satisfaction
cases.label: YES
cases.causal_structure: Group-level aggregates summarize heterogeneous individuals; group-level correlation does not imply the same relation at the individual level.
cases.key_insight: You cannot infer individual behavior reliably from group-level correlations.
cases.gold_rationale: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. The evidence is at an aggregate level, but the conclusion is about individuals. I would need individual-level data (or a defensible model of sorting into groups) before inferring how Company diversity percentage (group-level) relates to Individual satisfaction (individual-level) for a person.
cases.wise_refusal: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. The evidence is at an aggregate level, but the conclusion is about individuals. I would need individual-level data (or a defensible model of sorting into groups) before inferring how Company diversity percentage (group-level) relates to Individual satisfaction (individual-level) for a person.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Is Company diversity percentage (group-level) measured at an aggregate level while Individual satisfaction (individual-level) is an individual claim, and when/where does aggregation into Individual-level characteristics happen relative to measuring Individual satisfaction (individual-level)?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if you only have aggregate correlations: You cannot infer individual-level behavior; the relationship may be confounded by group-level factors.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if you have individual-level data within groups: Estimate the within-group association/effect and check whether it matches the aggregate pattern.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if there is sorting/selection into groups: Treat conclusions as CONDITIONAL unless you model the sorting mechanism or use a design that breaks it.

cases.scenario: Mental health researchers analyze survey data from adolescents reporting social media use between 0 and 4 hours daily. Within this range, they find a positive correlation: each additional hour of daily social media use corresponds to a 0.3-point increase on a depression symptoms scale (range 0-27). A concerned parent advocacy group extrapolates this finding to claim that teenagers using social media for 16 hours daily would have depression scores 4.8 points higher than non-users, characterizing extreme social media use as a severe mental health crisis requiring urgent intervention.
cases.claim: Teenagers using social media 16 hours daily would show proportionally elevated depression scores based on the linear relationship observed in the 0-4 hour range.
cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: X -> Y observed for X in [0, 4 hours], extrapolated to X = 16 hours without justification
cases.key_insight: Extreme usage levels (16 hours daily) represent a fundamentally different population with severe confounders; extrapolating correlations from typical usage ignores ceiling effects on outcomes and qualitative differences in who exhibits extreme behavior.
cases.gold_rationale: Extrapolating from 0-4 hours to 16 hours of daily social media use is unjustified for multiple reasons. First, 16-hour usage is physically unsustainable, leaving only 8 hours for sleep with no time for school, eating, or other activities, indicating severe confounding conditions. Second, depression scales have ceiling effects, preventing linear extrapolation beyond maximum scores. Third, individuals using social media 16 hours daily likely have pre-existing conditions (severe depression, social isolation, disability) that confound any observed correlation. The extreme usage domain has different population characteristics that invalidate extrapolation from typical users.
cases.wise_refusal: Extrapolating from 0-4 hours to 16 hours of daily social media use is unjustified for multiple reasons. First, 16-hour usage is physically unsustainable, leaving only 8 hours for sleep with no time for school, eating, or other activities, indicating severe confounding conditions. Second, depression scales have ceiling effects, preventing linear extrapolation beyond maximum scores. Third, individuals using social media 16 hours daily likely have pre-existing conditions (severe depression, social isolation, disability) that confound any observed correlation. The extreme usage domain has different population characteristics that invalidate extrapolation from typical users.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Does the linear correlation between social media use and depression observed from 0-4 hours/day extend to extreme usage levels like 16 hours/day?

conditional_answers.A: If the relationship is truly linear across all usage levels, extrapolation to extreme hours would be valid.
conditional_answers.B: If ceiling effects on depression scales or saturation of psychological mechanisms exist, the relationship plateaus at high usage.
conditional_answers.C: If extreme usage (16 hours) indicates severe underlying conditions that independently cause both behaviors, the correlation reflects confounding rather than direct causation.

cases.scenario:
A nonprofit reports that applicants from Prep Program A are accepted into selective colleges at a higher overall rate than applicants from Prep Program B. Donors conclude Program A is more effective and recommend expanding it.

A counselor points out that when acceptance rates are broken down by family income bracket (low-income vs higher-income), Program B has a higher acceptance rate in both brackets. Program A has more higher-income participants overall, while Program B serves mostly low-income participants.
cases.claim: applicants from Prep Program A are accepted into selective colleges at a higher overall rate than applicants from Prep Program B
cases.label: YES
cases.causal_structure: Z affects Y and differs in distribution across X; aggregating across Z reverses the subgroup acceptance-rate comparison.
cases.key_insight: Aggregate success rates can reverse within-group trends when group composition differs.
cases.gold_rationale: I can’t determine which program is causally better without baseline comparability (prior grades, support) and a credible assignment mechanism.
cases.wise_refusal: I can’t determine which program is causally better without baseline comparability (prior grades, support) and a credible assignment mechanism.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Was family income bracket known before students enrolled in Prep Program A vs. B, making it a true pre-enrollment stratifier?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if you only use overall acceptance rates: You may wrongly prefer Program A because it serves more higher-income students.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if you stratify or standardize by income bracket: Compare within strata (or compute standardized rates) to evaluate program performance.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if assignment to programs can be randomized within income strata: Then within-stratum differences can support a causal claim about program effectiveness.

cases.scenario:
A city report states that Bank X has a lower overall loan default rate than Bank Y, and officials argue Bank X has better underwriting practices.

When analysts stratify borrowers by credit-risk tier (prime vs subprime), Bank Y has a lower default rate in both tiers. The reversal occurs because Bank X approves a larger share of prime borrowers, while Bank Y serves more subprime borrowers overall.
cases.claim: A city report states that Bank X has a lower overall loan default rate than Bank Y, and officials argue Bank X has better underwriting practices
cases.label: YES
cases.causal_structure: Z strongly affects Y and the distribution of Z differs by X; aggregate defaults reverse the within-tier comparison.
cases.key_insight: Comparing institutions using aggregate outcomes is misleading when they serve different mixes of clients.
cases.gold_rationale: I can’t judge underwriting quality without consistent risk-tier measurement and a standardized comparison across the same risk distribution.
cases.wise_refusal: I can’t judge underwriting quality without consistent risk-tier measurement and a standardized comparison across the same risk distribution.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Is credit-risk tier assessed before borrowers choose a bank, making Z pre-treatment with respect to X?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if you compare only overall defaults: You may incorrectly attribute Bank X’s lower defaults to better underwriting.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if you compare within risk tiers or compute standardized defaults: Prefer the bank with lower within-tier defaults (and report a standardized overall rate).
conditional_answers.C: Answer if approval decisions themselves change the portfolio mix: Separate “mix effects” from “within-tier performance.”

cases.scenario:
A hospital network claims Clinic A provides better follow-up care because its overall 30-day readmission rate is lower than Clinic B’s.

When readmissions are broken down by patient age group (under 65 vs 65+), Clinic B has lower readmission rates in both groups. Clinic A treats a much larger share of younger patients, while Clinic B treats more older patients overall.
cases.claim: A hospital network claims Clinic A provides better follow-up care because its overall 30-day readmission rate is lower than Clinic B’s
cases.label: YES
cases.causal_structure: Z affects Y and differs by clinic; aggregating across Z reverses the subgroup comparison.
cases.key_insight: Overall metrics can hide within-group differences driven by demographic mix.
cases.gold_rationale: I can’t attribute readmission differences to care quality without case-mix adjustment and information on referral/triage processes.
cases.wise_refusal: I can’t attribute readmission differences to care quality without case-mix adjustment and information on referral/triage processes.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Was age determined before clinic selection (a true pre-treatment stratifier), or does clinic choice affect which ages are seen?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if you only look at overall readmissions: You might reward Clinic A incorrectly.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if you age-standardize or compare within age strata: The within-stratum comparison is more informative for care quality.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if clinics differ in referral patterns: Adjust for case mix and referral selection before drawing conclusions.

cases.scenario:
A company emails an anonymous satisfaction survey and reports that “85% of employees are satisfied.” Leadership concludes morale is high.

Only 30% of employees responded. Dissatisfied employees may be less likely to respond because they think nothing will change or fear being identified.
cases.claim: “85% of employees are satisfied
cases.label: YES
cases.causal_structure: Z affects response and satisfaction; conditioning on responders yields biased satisfaction estimate.
cases.key_insight: Survey results can be unrepresentative when response is selective.
cases.gold_rationale: I can’t infer company-wide morale without response-rate patterns and information about non-respondents.
cases.wise_refusal: I can’t infer company-wide morale without response-rate patterns and information about non-respondents.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Did dissatisfaction exist before employees chose whether to respond, or did the survey context change willingness to respond?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if response is random: Then the respondent rate estimates overall morale.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if dissatisfied employees avoid responding: Then results are biased upward; improve sampling/response incentives.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if response differs by team or manager: Use stratified follow-ups to assess representation.

cases.scenario:
A stakeholder argues that an intervention or group is riskier based on raw counts of flagged posts.
They point to a larger number of events in one group or after topic category.
But the groups have very different base sizes or exposure levels (posting volume differs), so comparing counts without denominators is misleading.
cases.claim: A stakeholder argues that an intervention or group is riskier based on raw counts of flagged posts
cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: Counts Y depend on both rate R and exposure N; N differs across X, so Y alone does not identify R.
cases.key_insight: A larger count can correspond to a lower rate when the base population is larger.
cases.gold_rationale: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. Raw counts of Event count (flagged posts) are not interpretable without exposure/population sizes. Please provide rates per capita/per exposure and the relevant denominator (and by subgroup/time) before concluding anything.
cases.wise_refusal: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. Raw counts of Event count (flagged posts) are not interpretable without exposure/population sizes. Please provide rates per capita/per exposure and the relevant denominator (and by subgroup/time) before concluding anything.
cases.hidden_timestamp: What is the relevant denominator at the time Event count (flagged posts) was counted, and are we comparing rates rather than raw counts?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if you only have raw counts of Event count (flagged posts): You cannot infer risk or effectiveness because the base population sizes may differ.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if you compute rates for Event count (flagged posts) with the correct denominator: Interpret the rate difference (risk per capita / per exposure) rather than the count difference.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if the base rates change over time or differ by subgroup: Use time- and subgroup-specific denominators; otherwise the conclusion is UNDETERMINED.

cases.scenario:
A health system introduced telemedicine visits in some clinics while others stayed in-person only. A summary report claims telemedicine reduced follow-up adherence because telemedicine clinics show a lower overall rate of patients completing a recommended follow-up within 30 days.

The evaluation compares 30-day follow-up completion rate in units that adopted the intervention versus units that did not. The aggregate comparison suggests the intervention has the opposite effect from what advocates expected.

When results are stratified by baseline chronic-disease burden of the clinic’s patient panel (high vs. low), the treated group shows the reverse pattern within *each* stratum. The discrepancy arises because the treated and untreated groups have very different mixtures of strata.
cases.claim: A health system introduced telemedicine visits in some clinics while others stayed in-person only

Z: baseline chronic-disease burden of the clinic’s patient panel (high vs. low)

cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: Z → Y and rollout implies P(Z|X=1) ≠ P(Z|X=0); aggregating across Z reverses within-stratum contrasts.
cases.key_insight: Stratum imbalance can make an intervention look harmful overall even if it helps in every subgroup (or vice versa).
cases.gold_rationale: I can’t estimate the intervention’s effect without knowing the rollout rule and verifying overlap in baseline chronic-disease burden of the clinic’s patient panel (high vs. low) between treated and untreated units.
cases.wise_refusal: I can’t estimate the intervention’s effect without knowing the rollout rule and verifying overlap in baseline chronic-disease burden of the clinic’s patient panel (high vs. low) between treated and untreated units.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Was baseline chronic-disease burden of the clinic’s patient panel (high vs. low) determined before adoption of the intervention (pre-treatment), making it legitimate to stratify on?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if you use only the overall treated vs. untreated difference: You may draw the wrong causal conclusion because treated units are concentrated in harder (or easier) strata.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if you compare within each baseline chronic-disease burden of the clinic’s patient panel (high vs. low) stratum or standardize: This addresses the imbalance and yields a more credible estimate.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if rollout is randomized within strata: Within-stratum comparisons can identify the causal effect more directly.

cases.causal_structure: X → C ← U → Y; conditioning on C opens X ↔ U, biasing X–Y within C=1.
cases.key_insight: Conditioning on an intermediate participation/compliance variable can create spurious treatment–outcome relationships.
cases.gold_rationale: I can’t make a causal claim from the compliant-only analysis without modeling why people become adherent (90%+ doses) and whether those determinants also affect Y.
cases.wise_refusal: I can’t make a causal claim from the compliant-only analysis without modeling why people become adherent (90%+ doses) and whether those determinants also affect Y.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Did compliance/participation (adherent (90%+ doses)) occur after assignment of X, making it a post-treatment variable affected by both X and U?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if compliance is unaffected by unobserved U (rare): Conditioning on C would be less problematic.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if U affects both compliance and outcomes: Conditioning on C induces collider bias; report intent-to-treat or avoid conditioning on C.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if you can instrument for compliance (with valid assumptions): You may estimate a causal effect for compliers, but this is assumption-heavy.

cases.scenario:
A professor uses an automated plagiarism detector that flags 2% of submissions. The professor says, “If the system flags you, you basically plagiarized,” and proposes an automatic penalty policy.

In reality, confirmed plagiarism is rare in this class, and the detector can produce false positives, especially on common template phrases.
cases.claim: A professor uses an automated plagiarism detector that flags 2% of submissions
cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: Signal is an imperfect indicator of a rare event; posterior probability depends on π and error rates.
cases.key_insight: A positive flag can be misleading when the underlying event is rare or when conditional probabilities are confused.
cases.gold_rationale: I can’t give the probability without the base rate and the signal’s accuracy (false positive/negative rates); ignoring them risks major misinterpretation.

cases.scenario:
A hospital system compares two treatments for a chronic condition: Treatment A (new) and Treatment B (standard). Hospital leadership reports that Treatment A has a higher overall recovery rate and decides to adopt it system-wide.
However, when outcomes are analyzed separately for mild cases and severe cases, Treatment B has a higher recovery rate in both severity groups.
The apparent superiority of Treatment A arises because it is used far more often for mild cases, while Treatment B is disproportionately used for severe cases.
cases.claim: Treatment A has a higher overall recovery rate and decides to adopt it system-wide
cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: Disease severity (Z) influences both treatment assignment (X) and recovery (Y). Aggregating outcomes across severity levels reverses the treatment comparison.
cases.key_insight: An intervention may appear effective overall while being inferior within every relevant subgroup.
cases.gold_rationale: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. Please report Recovery outcome by the key strata (e.g., Disease severity (mild / severe) if that is the stratifier), and compute a standardized effect; the aggregate comparison can reverse when Treatment type (A vs. B) is unevenly applied across strata.
cases.wise_refusal: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. Please report Recovery outcome by the key strata (e.g., Disease severity (mild / severe) if that is the stratifier), and compute a standardized effect; the aggregate comparison can reverse when Treatment type (A vs. B) is unevenly applied across strata.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Was Disease severity (mild / severe) determined before Treatment type (A vs. B) was chosen, and could Disease severity (mild / severe) have influenced the choice of Treatment type (A vs. B) before Recovery outcome was measured?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if you only compare aggregates: The apparent effect of Treatment type (A vs. B) on Recovery outcome may be reversed because the mix of subgroups differs between Treatment type (A vs. B) arms.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if you compare within strata after stratifying/standardizing by Disease severity (mild / severe): Use the within-stratum differences (or a standardized effect). If Treatment type (A vs. B) improves Recovery outcome in each stratum, prefer Treatment type (A vs. B) even if the aggregate looks worse.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if Treatment type (A vs. B) can be randomized within strata: Then the within-stratum comparison identifies the causal effect; report both stratum-specific and standardized estimates.

cases.scenario: A school district offers an optional after-school tutoring program. Students who enroll show 15% higher test scores than non-participants. The district claims the tutoring program causes improved academic performance.
cases.claim: The after-school tutoring program causes higher test scores.
cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: Z -> X, Z -> Y (Confounded by self-selection)
cases.key_insight: Voluntary program participation creates selection bias when the same factors driving enrollment also affect outcomes.
cases.gold_rationale: I cannot confirm this causal claim. Students who voluntarily enroll in tutoring may differ systematically from non-participants in motivation, parental support, or baseline ability. Without random assignment or controlling for these selection factors, the observed difference may reflect who chooses tutoring rather than what tutoring causes.
cases.wise_refusal: I cannot confirm this causal claim. Students who voluntarily enroll in tutoring may differ systematically from non-participants in motivation, parental support, or baseline ability. Without random assignment or controlling for these selection factors, the observed difference may reflect who chooses tutoring rather than what tutoring causes.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Did students self-select into the tutoring program based on pre-existing characteristics that also affect test scores?

conditional_answers.A: If enrollment was random or mandatory, the 15% improvement can be attributed to the program.
conditional_answers.B: If motivated students with involved parents disproportionately enrolled, the improvement reflects selection bias, not program effect.

cases.scenario: A job training agency surveys graduates who found employment within 6 months. Among these employed graduates, 85% report the program was helpful. The agency concludes the training program is highly effective for all participants.
cases.claim: The job training program is effective for all participants.
cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: X -> Z -> Survey Inclusion, Y measured only among included
cases.key_insight: Sampling on a post-treatment outcome excludes cases where treatment may have failed.
cases.gold_rationale: I cannot confirm this causal claim. By surveying only graduates who found employment, the agency samples on a post-treatment outcome. Participants who remained unemployed—potentially those for whom the program failed—are excluded. The 85% helpfulness rating may not generalize to all participants.
cases.wise_refusal: I cannot confirm this causal claim. By surveying only graduates who found employment, the agency samples on a post-treatment outcome. Participants who remained unemployed—potentially those for whom the program failed—are excluded. The 85% helpfulness rating may not generalize to all participants.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Does the survey exclude participants who did not find employment, potentially those for whom the program was least effective?

conditional_answers.A: If all participants were surveyed regardless of employment status, the 85% satisfaction rate reflects overall program effectiveness.
conditional_answers.B: If only employed graduates were surveyed, the sample excludes those who may have found the program unhelpful, inflating effectiveness estimates.

cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: Z -> X, Z -> Y (Motivation confounds both)
cases.key_insight: Volunteer bias occurs when those who self-select into treatment differ in ways that independently affect the outcome.
cases.gold_rationale: I cannot confirm this causal claim. People who voluntarily attend smoking cessation classes likely have higher baseline motivation to quit than non-attendees. Without comparing to a control group with similar motivation levels, the 40% quit rate may reflect who attends rather than the causal effect of attendance.
cases.wise_refusal: I cannot confirm this causal claim. People who voluntarily attend smoking cessation classes likely have higher baseline motivation to quit than non-attendees. Without comparing to a control group with similar motivation levels, the 40% quit rate may reflect who attends rather than the causal effect of attendance.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Were attendees already more motivated to quit smoking than the general smoking population before attending?

conditional_answers.A: If attendance was randomly assigned among smokers, the 40% quit rate can be attributed to the classes.
conditional_answers.B: If attendees self-selected based on high motivation to quit, they may have quit at high rates regardless of the classes.

cases.scenario: A microfinance organization tracks loan recipients over 5 years. Among those still in the program, average income increased 60%. Many participants left the program, with exit interviews unavailable. The organization claims microfinance causes substantial income growth.
cases.claim: Microfinance participation causes 60% income growth.
cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: X -> Y -> Attrition (Outcome affects continued observation)
cases.key_insight: Differential attrition based on outcomes creates survivorship bias in longitudinal program evaluations.
cases.gold_rationale: I cannot confirm this causal claim. Without data on participants who left the program, we cannot determine if attrition was related to outcomes. If those experiencing business failures or income decline dropped out, the 60% growth among remaining participants overstates the program's true causal effect.
cases.wise_refusal: I cannot confirm this causal claim. Without data on participants who left the program, we cannot determine if attrition was related to outcomes. If those experiencing business failures or income decline dropped out, the 60% growth among remaining participants overstates the program's true causal effect.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Did participants who experienced poor outcomes leave the program, creating a biased sample of remaining participants?

conditional_answers.A: If attrition was random and unrelated to income outcomes, the 60% growth among stayers reflects the program effect.
conditional_answers.B: If participants who failed to increase income dropped out, the remaining sample is positively selected, overstating the program's effect.

cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: Z -> Response, Z -> Y (Enthusiasm affects both)
cases.key_insight: Non-response bias occurs when the probability of responding correlates with the outcome of interest.
cases.gold_rationale: I cannot confirm this causal claim. Survey respondents may not represent all registered voters. If candidate supporters are more enthusiastic and thus more likely to respond, the 70% support rate among respondents overestimates true population support. Response rate and respondent characteristics must be examined.
cases.wise_refusal: I cannot confirm this causal claim. Survey respondents may not represent all registered voters. If candidate supporters are more enthusiastic and thus more likely to respond, the 70% support rate among respondents overestimates true population support. Response rate and respondent characteristics must be examined.

conditional_answers.A: If response rates were equal across supporter and non-supporter groups, the 70% reflects true population support.
conditional_answers.B: If supporters were more likely to respond due to enthusiasm, the 70% overestimates actual population support.

cases.scenario: A study of prison inmates finds that those with mental illness are less likely to have completed high school than inmates without mental illness. Researchers conclude mental illness causes educational failure in the general population.
cases.claim: Mental illness causes lower educational attainment in the general population.
cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: X -> Z, Y -> Z (Both affect incarceration); conditioning on Z creates bias
cases.key_insight: Berkson's bias occurs when sampling conditions on a common effect of two variables, creating spurious associations.
cases.gold_rationale: I cannot confirm this causal claim. By studying only incarcerated individuals, the research conditions on a collider. Both mental illness and low education may independently increase incarceration risk. Within the prison sample, this creates a spurious negative correlation that may not exist in the general population.
cases.wise_refusal: I cannot confirm this causal claim. By studying only incarcerated individuals, the research conditions on a collider. Both mental illness and low education may independently increase incarceration risk. Within the prison sample, this creates a spurious negative correlation that may not exist in the general population.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Does restricting the sample to incarcerated individuals create a spurious relationship between mental illness and education?

conditional_answers.A: If the prison population is representative of the general population regarding mental illness and education, the finding generalizes.
conditional_answers.B: If incarceration is independently associated with both mental illness and low education, conditioning on incarceration creates Berkson's bias.

cases.wise_refusal: I cannot confirm this causal claim. Twitter users are not a representative sample of the general public. The platform skews toward certain demographics (younger, urban, higher education) that correlate with political views. The 65% progressive support on Twitter cannot be generalized to the broader population.

cases.scenario: A meta-analysis of studies on class size reduction finds an average effect of 0.3 standard deviations improvement in test scores. The analysis includes only published, peer-reviewed studies. Policymakers conclude class size reduction reliably improves outcomes.
cases.claim: Class size reduction reliably causes a 0.3 SD improvement in test scores.
cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: True Effect -> Study Result -> Publication (positive results more likely published)
cases.key_insight: Publication bias in meta-analyses inflates effect estimates by excluding null findings from the evidence base.
cases.gold_rationale: I cannot confirm this causal claim. Meta-analyses of only published studies may suffer from publication bias—studies finding null results are less likely to be published. The 0.3 SD effect may overestimate the true impact if the 'file drawer' contains many null findings. Funnel plots and unpublished study searches are needed.
cases.wise_refusal: I cannot confirm this causal claim. Meta-analyses of only published studies may suffer from publication bias—studies finding null results are less likely to be published. The 0.3 SD effect may overestimate the true impact if the 'file drawer' contains many null findings. Funnel plots and unpublished study searches are needed.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Are studies with null or negative results less likely to be published, biasing the meta-analysis toward positive findings?

conditional_answers.A: If published and unpublished studies show similar effects, the 0.3 SD estimate is unbiased.
conditional_answers.B: If studies showing no effect remain unpublished, the meta-analysis overestimates the true effect of class size reduction.

cases.scenario: A city's bike-sharing program reports that regular users have 30% lower rates of cardiovascular disease than non-users. The city concludes that bike-sharing causes improved cardiovascular health.

Z: Baseline health status and fitness level

cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: Z (baseline health) -> X (bike usage), Z -> Y (CVD risk)

Bike-sharing users may be systematically healthier than non-users at baseline—they are mobile, active, and health-conscious enough to choose cycling. Without controlling for pre-existing health status and activity levels, the 30% lower cardiovascular disease rate may reflect healthy participant bias.
cases.wise_refusal: I cannot confirm this causal claim. Bike-sharing users may be systematically healthier than non-users at baseline—they are mobile, active, and health-conscious enough to choose cycling. Without controlling for pre-existing health status and activity levels, the 30% lower cardiovascular disease rate may reflect healthy participant bias.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Are bike-sharing users already healthier than non-users before they started using the program?

conditional_answers.A: If users and non-users had similar baseline health before program adoption, the 30% reduction reflects program causation.
conditional_answers.B: If healthier, more active individuals preferentially adopt bike-sharing, the observed difference reflects pre-existing health disparities.

cases.scenario: A business magazine profiles 50 successful startups and identifies common traits: founders worked 80+ hours weekly, pivoted multiple times, and rejected early acquisition offers. The magazine concludes these behaviors cause startup success.
cases.claim: Working 80+ hours weekly, pivoting, and rejecting acquisition offers cause startup success.
cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: X -> Y? but only Y=success observed (failures invisible)
cases.key_insight: Survivorship bias occurs when we study only survivors and miss that non-survivors had the same characteristics.
cases.gold_rationale: I cannot confirm this causal claim. This analysis suffers from survivorship bias—only successful startups were studied. Failed startups that exhibited identical behaviors (long hours, pivots, rejected offers) are invisible because they no longer exist. Without studying failures, we cannot determine if these behaviors cause success.
cases.wise_refusal: I cannot confirm this causal claim. This analysis suffers from survivorship bias—only successful startups were studied. Failed startups that exhibited identical behaviors (long hours, pivots, rejected offers) are invisible because they no longer exist. Without studying failures, we cannot determine if these behaviors cause success.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Did the analysis include failed startups that exhibited the same behaviors but are no longer visible?

conditional_answers.A: If failed startups rarely exhibited these behaviors, the behaviors may contribute to success.
conditional_answers.B: If many failed startups also worked long hours, pivoted, and rejected offers, these behaviors don't differentiate success from failure.

cases.scenario: A university reports that students who complete its rigorous engineering program earn average starting salaries of $85,000. Administrators claim the program's rigor causes high earning potential.
cases.claim: The rigorous engineering program causes high earning potential.

Z: Students who dropped out due to rigor

cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: Ability -> Survival, Ability -> Y; X -> Survival (rigor filters)
cases.key_insight: Rigorous programs may show good outcomes because they filter to high-ability survivors, not because rigor adds value.
cases.gold_rationale: I cannot confirm this causal claim. The $85,000 salary applies only to program completers—students who survived the rigor. If the difficulty caused weaker students to drop out, the remaining graduates are a selected group whose high earnings may reflect their pre-existing ability rather than the program's causal effect.
cases.wise_refusal: I cannot confirm this causal claim. The $85,000 salary applies only to program completers—students who survived the rigor. If the difficulty caused weaker students to drop out, the remaining graduates are a selected group whose high earnings may reflect their pre-existing ability rather than the program's causal effect.
cases.hidden_timestamp: What happened to students who started but could not complete the rigorous program?

conditional_answers.A: If most students complete the program regardless of rigor, the $85,000 reflects program value.
conditional_answers.B: If rigor causes many students to drop out, survivors may be a selected high-ability group whose earnings would be high regardless.

cases.scenario: An investment database shows that active mutual funds have outperformed passive index funds by 2% annually over the past 20 years. Analysts conclude active management causes superior returns.
cases.claim: Active fund management causes superior investment returns.

Z: Funds that closed due to poor performance

cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: X -> Y -> Survival (poor Y leads to fund closure)
cases.key_insight: Financial databases often exclude failed funds, making surviving active funds appear to outperform.
cases.gold_rationale: I cannot confirm this causal claim. Mutual fund databases typically suffer from survivorship bias—poorly performing funds merge or liquidate and disappear from historical records. The 2% outperformance may reflect that only successful active funds survived to be measured, not that active management causes better returns.
cases.wise_refusal: I cannot confirm this causal claim. Mutual fund databases typically suffer from survivorship bias—poorly performing funds merge or liquidate and disappear from historical records. The 2% outperformance may reflect that only successful active funds survived to be measured, not that active management causes better returns.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Does the database include funds that closed during the 20-year period due to poor performance?

conditional_answers.A: If the database includes all funds that existed at any point, the 2% outperformance reflects true active management value.
conditional_answers.B: If poorly performing funds closed and exited the database, only survivors remain, inflating apparent active management returns.

cases.scenario: During wartime, engineers examine returning aircraft and find bullet holes concentrated on wings and fuselage, but rarely on engines. They propose reinforcing wings and fuselage to improve aircraft survival.
cases.claim: Reinforcing wings and fuselage will improve aircraft survival rates.
cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: Hit Location -> Survival; only survivors observed
cases.key_insight: The classic Wald example: damage on survivors indicates survivable hit locations, not vulnerable areas needing protection.
cases.gold_rationale: I cannot confirm this causal claim. The damage pattern comes only from returning aircraft—the survivors. Aircraft hit in engines likely did not survive to be examined. The absence of engine damage in returned planes suggests engine hits are fatal. Armor should protect engines, not the visibly damaged areas.
cases.wise_refusal: I cannot confirm this causal claim. The damage pattern comes only from returning aircraft—the survivors. Aircraft hit in engines likely did not survive to be examined. The absence of engine damage in returned planes suggests engine hits are fatal. Armor should protect engines, not the visibly damaged areas.
cases.hidden_timestamp: What does the damage pattern on aircraft that did not return look like?

conditional_answers.A: If non-returning aircraft had similar damage patterns, reinforcing observed damage areas makes sense.
conditional_answers.B: If aircraft hit in engines did not return, the observed pattern reflects survivorship—engines need reinforcement, not wings.

cases.scenario: A documentary interviews 20 famous musicians who all dropped out of formal music education to pursue their passion independently. It concludes that formal music education hinders musical success.
cases.claim: Formal music education hinders achieving fame as a musician.

X.name: Dropping out of formal music education

Z: Unknown musicians who also dropped out

cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: X -> Y? but only Y=famous is visible
cases.key_insight: Success stories of dropouts ignore the invisible mass of dropouts who failed.
cases.gold_rationale: I cannot confirm this causal claim. The documentary samples only famous musicians—the survivors. For every famous dropout, countless musicians also dropped out and never achieved recognition. Without studying the failure rate among dropouts, we cannot conclude that leaving formal education causes success.
cases.wise_refusal: I cannot confirm this causal claim. The documentary samples only famous musicians—the survivors. For every famous dropout, countless musicians also dropped out and never achieved recognition. Without studying the failure rate among dropouts, we cannot conclude that leaving formal education causes success.
cases.hidden_timestamp: How many musicians dropped out and never achieved fame?

conditional_answers.A: If most musicians who drop out achieve fame, formal education may indeed hinder success.
conditional_answers.B: If thousands dropped out and failed while a few succeeded, dropping out does not cause success—it may even reduce odds.

cases.scenario: Urban planners note that century-old buildings in historic districts are remarkably well-constructed compared to modern buildings. They conclude that construction quality has declined over time.
cases.claim: Building construction quality has declined from the past to the present.

Z: Poorly-built old buildings that were demolished

cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: Quality -> Survival; only high-quality old buildings survive to present
cases.key_insight: Old artifacts that survive to the present are non-random samples of their era's production.
cases.gold_rationale: I cannot confirm this causal claim. The surviving century-old buildings represent the best of their era—structures that withstood time. Poorly-built buildings from the same period collapsed, were condemned, or demolished decades ago. Comparing survivors to all current buildings creates a biased quality comparison.
cases.wise_refusal: I cannot confirm this causal claim. The surviving century-old buildings represent the best of their era—structures that withstood time. Poorly-built buildings from the same period collapsed, were condemned, or demolished decades ago. Comparing survivors to all current buildings creates a biased quality comparison.
cases.hidden_timestamp: What happened to poorly-constructed buildings from a century ago?

conditional_answers.A: If most century-old buildings survived regardless of quality, old buildings were indeed better built.
conditional_answers.B: If poorly-built old buildings collapsed or were demolished, only the best-constructed survivors remain for comparison.

cases.scenario: A hospital reports that cancer patients who completed all 12 rounds of chemotherapy had 5-year survival rates of 70%. Oncologists conclude that completing chemotherapy causes higher survival.
cases.claim: Completing all chemotherapy rounds causes higher cancer survival rates.

Z: Patients who died before completing treatment

cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: Disease Severity -> Completion, Disease Severity -> Y
cases.key_insight: Treatment completion can be a marker of underlying health status rather than a cause of outcomes.
cases.gold_rationale: I cannot confirm this causal claim. Patients who complete all 12 rounds are necessarily alive at that point—they survived long enough to complete treatment. Those with aggressive disease may have died before completion. The 70% survival rate among completers partly reflects that completers were healthier or had less aggressive cancer.
cases.wise_refusal: I cannot confirm this causal claim. Patients who complete all 12 rounds are necessarily alive at that point—they survived long enough to complete treatment. Those with aggressive disease may have died before completion. The 70% survival rate among completers partly reflects that completers were healthier or had less aggressive cancer.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Did some patients fail to complete chemotherapy because they died during treatment?

conditional_answers.A: If non-completers chose to stop for reasons unrelated to disease progression, completion may causally improve survival.
conditional_answers.B: If patients with aggressive disease died before completing treatment, completers are a selected healthier group.

cases.scenario: A business school study of 30 highly successful tech companies finds they all had unconventional corporate cultures (flexible hours, flat hierarchies, unlimited vacation). The study concludes these cultural practices cause company success.
cases.claim: Unconventional corporate culture causes tech company success.
cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: X -> Y? (unobserved: many with X had Y=failure)
cases.key_insight: Corporate culture studies of successful firms ignore failed firms with identical cultures.
cases.gold_rationale: I cannot confirm this causal claim. The study examines only successful companies—the survivors. Countless tech startups adopted similar unconventional cultures but failed and disappeared from view. Without including failed companies in the analysis, we cannot determine whether culture caused success or successful companies simply survived to be studied.
cases.wise_refusal: I cannot confirm this causal claim. The study examines only successful companies—the survivors. Countless tech startups adopted similar unconventional cultures but failed and disappeared from view. Without including failed companies in the analysis, we cannot determine whether culture caused success or successful companies simply survived to be studied.
cases.hidden_timestamp: How many tech companies with unconventional cultures failed and are no longer visible?

conditional_answers.A: If few companies with unconventional cultures failed, such practices may contribute to success.
conditional_answers.B: If many startups adopted similar cultures but failed, these practices don't differentiate success from failure.

cases.scenario: A study at an elite university finds that among admitted students, those with high athletic ability have lower academic test scores than non-athletes. Researchers conclude athletic ability negatively affects academic performance.
cases.claim: Athletic ability causes lower academic performance.
cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: X -> Admission <- Y; conditioning on Admission biases X-Y relationship
cases.key_insight: Collider bias: conditioning on a common effect creates spurious associations between its independent causes.
cases.gold_rationale: I cannot confirm this causal claim. University admission is a collider affected by both athletic and academic ability. Among admitted students, if one path to admission (athletics) is high, the other (academics) need not be as high. This creates a spurious negative correlation within the admitted sample that doesn't exist in the general population.
cases.wise_refusal: I cannot confirm this causal claim. University admission is a collider affected by both athletic and academic ability. Among admitted students, if one path to admission (athletics) is high, the other (academics) need not be as high. This creates a spurious negative correlation within the admitted sample that doesn't exist in the general population.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Does the university admit students based on both athletic and academic merit, creating a collider?

conditional_answers.A: If admission is based solely on academics, the athletic-academic correlation among admitted students reflects a true relationship.
conditional_answers.B: If admission values both athletics and academics, high athletic ability can compensate for lower academics, creating a spurious negative correlation.

cases.scenario: A dating app study finds that among people in relationships, those who are very attractive tend to have less wealthy partners, and vice versa. Researchers conclude attractiveness causes people to choose less wealthy partners.
cases.claim: Physical attractiveness causes people to select less wealthy partners.
cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: Attractiveness -> Relationship <- Wealth; conditioning creates negative correlation
cases.key_insight: The attractiveness-wealth trade-off in partners may be collider bias, not a real preference pattern.
cases.gold_rationale: I cannot confirm this causal claim. Being in a relationship is a collider—both attractiveness and wealth can independently help secure partners. Among those who successfully partnered, high attractiveness makes high partner wealth less necessary, and vice versa. This creates a spurious trade-off that doesn't reflect actual preferences.
cases.wise_refusal: I cannot confirm this causal claim. Being in a relationship is a collider—both attractiveness and wealth can independently help secure partners. Among those who successfully partnered, high attractiveness makes high partner wealth less necessary, and vice versa. This creates a spurious trade-off that doesn't reflect actual preferences.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Is being in a relationship influenced by both attractiveness and wealth, creating collider bias?

conditional_answers.A: If relationship formation is unrelated to attractiveness and wealth combined, the trade-off reflects true preferences.
conditional_answers.B: If either attractiveness or wealth helps secure partners, conditioning on having a partner creates a spurious negative correlation.

cases.scenario: A study of famous actors finds that those known primarily for talent tend to have more personal scandals than those known for their looks. Researchers conclude acting talent causes personal instability.
cases.claim: Acting talent causes personal instability and scandals.
cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: Talent -> Fame <- Attractiveness; Instability -> Fame path moderated
cases.key_insight: Multiple paths to success (fame) create collider bias when analyzing only successful individuals.
cases.gold_rationale: I cannot confirm this causal claim. Fame is a collider—both talent and physical attractiveness can independently lead to becoming famous. Among famous actors, those who achieved fame primarily through talent may have succeeded despite personal issues, while attractive actors may have faced higher personal stability thresholds. The correlation is spurious.
cases.wise_refusal: I cannot confirm this causal claim. Fame is a collider—both talent and physical attractiveness can independently lead to becoming famous. Among famous actors, those who achieved fame primarily through talent may have succeeded despite personal issues, while attractive actors may have faced higher personal stability thresholds. The correlation is spurious.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Can both talent and attractiveness independently lead to fame, creating collider bias when studying famous people?

conditional_answers.A: If fame requires both talent and stability, talented famous actors being unstable would be surprising.
conditional_answers.B: If either talent or looks can produce fame, among the famous, those with exceptional talent needed less of other qualities to succeed.

cases.scenario: Among employed workers at a company, researchers find that those with more years of education earn less than expected given their experience. They conclude that education has diminishing returns in this workplace.
cases.claim: Education has diminishing or negative returns in this workplace.
cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: Education -> Employment <- Other factors; conditioning biases Education-Earnings
cases.key_insight: Within-firm analyses suffer from collider bias when hiring considers multiple substitutable factors.
cases.gold_rationale: I cannot confirm this causal claim. Employment at this company is a collider affected by multiple factors. If highly educated candidates are hired despite weaker networks or experience, while less educated hires needed stronger networks, conditioning on employment creates a spurious negative education-earnings pattern within the firm.
cases.wise_refusal: I cannot confirm this causal claim. Employment at this company is a collider affected by multiple factors. If highly educated candidates are hired despite weaker networks or experience, while less educated hires needed stronger networks, conditioning on employment creates a spurious negative education-earnings pattern within the firm.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Does the company hire based on a combination of education and other factors that substitute for each other?

conditional_answers.A: If the company hires purely based on education, the education-earnings pattern reflects true returns.
conditional_answers.B: If education and experience/connections substitute in hiring decisions, highly educated employees who were hired may have weaker other qualifications.

cases.scenario: A hospital study finds that among hospitalized patients, smokers have better outcomes from heart attacks than non-smokers. Cardiologists are puzzled and some suggest smoking may be protective.
cases.claim: Smoking is protective against heart attack mortality.
cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: Smoking -> Hospitalization <- Severity; conditioning on hospitalization biases comparison
cases.key_insight: The smoker's paradox arises from collider bias when comparing outcomes conditional on hospitalization.
cases.gold_rationale: I cannot confirm this causal claim. This is known as the 'smoker's paradox.' Hospitalization is a collider—smokers may be hospitalized for heart attacks at younger ages or lower severity thresholds. Non-smokers hospitalized for heart attacks may have more severe underlying disease. The apparent protective effect is collider bias, not causation.
cases.wise_refusal: I cannot confirm this causal claim. This is known as the 'smoker's paradox.' Hospitalization is a collider—smokers may be hospitalized for heart attacks at younger ages or lower severity thresholds. Non-smokers hospitalized for heart attacks may have more severe underlying disease. The apparent protective effect is collider bias, not causation.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Does hospitalization for heart attacks depend on both smoking status and other risk factors, creating collider bias?

conditional_answers.A: If hospitalization rates are equal across smoking status and other risk factors, the smoker advantage is real.
conditional_answers.B: If smokers are hospitalized for less severe heart attacks (smoking causes earlier symptoms), they appear to have better outcomes due to collider bias.

cases.scenario: News analysis finds that among reported crimes, those committed by immigrants are more likely to involve violence than crimes by citizens. Analysts conclude immigrants are more prone to violent crime.
cases.claim: Immigrants are more prone to violent crime than citizens.
cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: Immigrant Status -> News Coverage <- Crime Severity
cases.key_insight: Media selection bias creates collider bias when newsworthiness depends on multiple factors.
cases.gold_rationale: I cannot confirm this causal claim. News coverage is a collider affected by both perpetrator background (immigrant status is more newsworthy) and crime severity. Minor crimes by immigrants may receive coverage while similar crimes by citizens do not. Among reported crimes, this creates a spurious association between immigrant status and violence.
cases.wise_refusal: I cannot confirm this causal claim. News coverage is a collider affected by both perpetrator background (immigrant status is more newsworthy) and crime severity. Minor crimes by immigrants may receive coverage while similar crimes by citizens do not. Among reported crimes, this creates a spurious association between immigrant status and violence.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Does newsworthiness depend on both perpetrator status and crime severity, creating collider bias in news samples?

conditional_answers.A: If news reports crimes equally regardless of perpetrator background, the pattern reflects true differences.
conditional_answers.B: If immigrant crimes are more newsworthy, minor immigrant crimes get reported while only severe citizen crimes make news—creating a spurious pattern.

cases.scenario: An analysis of funded research projects finds that projects with novel methodologies tend to have less distinguished principal investigators. Reviewers conclude novel methods are developed by less experienced researchers.

cases.label: NO
cases.causal_structure: Novelty -> Funding <- Reputation; conditioning creates negative correlation
cases.key_insight: Multiple criteria for success (funding) create spurious trade-offs among successful applicants.
