cases.scenario: A city implemented rent control in 2017. Five years later, the rental housing stock had decreased by 15% as landlords converted units to condos or let buildings deteriorate. New construction also slowed significantly.
cases.label: VALID
cases.key_insight: Deterministic behavioral responses to policy incentives can support valid counterfactuals even when mechanisms are complex.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is valid despite behavioral intermediaries because landlord responses to price controls are well-documented and predictable economic behaviors.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is valid despite behavioral intermediaries because landlord responses to price controls are well-documented and predictable economic behaviors.

cases.scenario: A city removed a major highway in 2016, replacing it with a boulevard. Traffic in the corridor decreased by 40%, but some traffic shifted to parallel routes, and some trips were simply not made.
cases.label: INVALID
cases.key_insight: Infrastructure changes trigger behavioral responses that complicate counterfactual reasoning about transportation.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual depends on assumptions about induced demand and baseline traffic growth. Highway presence itself influences demand, making simple counterfactuals problematic.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on assumptions about induced demand and baseline traffic growth. Highway presence itself influences demand, making simple counterfactuals problematic.

cases.scenario: A city implemented a vaccination campaign that achieved 85% coverage. COVID-19 hospitalizations dropped by 70% compared to similar unvaccinated cities. Individual vaccine efficacy was estimated at 80% against severe disease.
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.key_insight: Probabilistic disease transmission makes precise counterfactual quantification dependent on model assumptions.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual requires specifying epidemiological model assumptions. Different models of disease spread and immunity would yield different counterfactual estimates.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual requires specifying epidemiological model assumptions. Different models of disease spread and immunity would yield different counterfactual estimates.

cases.scenario: A job training program served 1,000 unemployed workers. After six months, 60% of participants found employment compared to 40% of similar non-participants. The local unemployment rate was declining generally during this period.
cases.label: INVALID
cases.key_insight: Self-selection into programs creates bias that invalidates naive counterfactual comparisons.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is invalid due to selection bias. Participants who chose to enroll likely differed systematically from non-participants, confounding the comparison.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid due to selection bias. Participants who chose to enroll likely differed systematically from non-participants, confounding the comparison.

cases.scenario: A corrupt politician was exposed by both an investigative journalist and a whistleblower independently on the same day. Either revelation alone would have been sufficient to force resignation. The politician resigned within 24 hours.
cases.label: INVALID
cases.key_insight: Symmetric overdetermination renders neither individual cause necessary for the effect.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is invalid due to overdetermination. The whistleblower's revelation was independently sufficient to cause the resignation.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid due to overdetermination. The whistleblower's revelation was independently sufficient to cause the resignation.

cases.scenario: A civil rights organization filed a lawsuit to desegregate schools in 1962. Before the court ruled, Congress passed legislation mandating desegregation nationally. The schools in question desegregated following the legislation.
cases.label: INVALID
cases.key_insight: Preemptive overdetermination occurs when a backup cause would have produced the same effect through a different pathway.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is invalid because the congressional legislation provided an independent, sufficient cause that preempted the lawsuit's potential effect.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid because the congressional legislation provided an independent, sufficient cause that preempted the lawsuit's potential effect.

cases.scenario: A peace treaty was signed after both economic sanctions and military pressure were applied to the aggressor nation. Intelligence reports indicated that either pressure alone would have been sufficient to force negotiations.
cases.label: INVALID
cases.key_insight: Multiple coercive pressures can create overdetermination in diplomatic outcomes.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is invalid because military pressure provided an independent sufficient cause for the treaty.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid because military pressure provided an independent sufficient cause for the treaty.

cases.scenario: A study showed that college graduates earn more than non-graduates. Further analysis revealed that the earnings premium primarily comes through access to professional networks and credentialing, not directly from knowledge gained.
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.key_insight: Mediator structures may not remain stable under hypothetical population-level interventions.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual requires specifying whether credential and network effects would persist if college attendance became universal. General equilibrium effects could change the mediator pathways.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual requires specifying whether credential and network effects would persist if college attendance became universal. General equilibrium effects could change the mediator pathways.

cases.scenario: A study of elected officials found that those who are both charismatic and policy-competent tend to win elections. Among winners, charisma and competence appear negatively correlated because each can substitute for the other.
cases.label: INVALID
cases.key_insight: Collider structures create spurious associations that do not support causal counterfactuals.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is invalid because it relies on a correlation induced by collider bias. The negative relationship only appears because we condition on election victory.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid because it relies on a correlation induced by collider bias. The negative relationship only appears because we condition on election victory.

cases.scenario: A city increased police presence in high-crime neighborhoods. Crime reports initially increased, then decreased. Analysis suggested increased reporting due to police presence preceded actual crime reduction through deterrence.
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.key_insight: Feedback loop structures create time-dependent counterfactual effects.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual requires specifying the time horizon. Short-term and long-term effects differ due to the feedback loop structure.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual requires specifying the time horizon. Short-term and long-term effects differ due to the feedback loop structure.

cases.scenario: A study found that people whose friends exercised regularly were more likely to exercise themselves. The social influence appeared to flow through close network ties, not just social comparison or shared environments.
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.key_insight: Network structures confound social influence with selection into relationships.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual depends on whether the correlation reflects friend influence or friend selection based on shared preferences.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on whether the correlation reflects friend influence or friend selection based on shared preferences.

cases.scenario: A country's industrial policy in the 1960s focused on heavy industry. By the 1990s, the country had become a manufacturing powerhouse. However, global trade liberalization in the 1980s also opened export markets during this period.
cases.label: VALID
cases.key_insight: Long temporal gaps between cause and effect allow intervening factors that complicate counterfactual reasoning.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual requires specifying whether the industrial policy was necessary given subsequent global changes, or whether trade liberalization alone could have produced similar results.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual requires specifying whether the industrial policy was necessary given subsequent global changes, or whether trade liberalization alone could have produced similar results.

cases.scenario: A country adopted a proportional representation electoral system in 1920. By 2020, it had a stable multi-party democracy. Scholars argue early institutional choices create path-dependent political development.
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.key_insight: Path dependence complicates counterfactuals about institutional choices by suggesting different paths lead to different equilibria.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual depends on whether democratic stability requires specific institutional forms or can emerge through multiple pathways. Path dependence suggests the development trajectory would differ.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on whether democratic stability requires specific institutional forms or can emerge through multiple pathways. Path dependence suggests the development trajectory would differ.

cases.scenario: A country invested heavily in solar panel manufacturing in 2010 when the technology was nascent. By 2020, it dominated the global market with 80% share. Later entrants faced established supply chains and economies of scale.
cases.label: INVALID
cases.key_insight: First mover advantages create temporal asymmetries that invalidate simple investment counterfactuals.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is invalid because first mover advantages are path-dependent. The early entrant's accumulated learning and scale cannot be replicated by later entrants regardless of investment.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid because first mover advantages are path-dependent. The early entrant's accumulated learning and scale cannot be replicated by later entrants regardless of investment.

cases.scenario: A region experienced gradual environmental degradation from industrial pollution over 50 years. By 2020, ecosystem collapse occurred. Scientists identified a tipping point crossed around 2010 after cumulative damage reached a threshold.
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.key_insight: Cumulative effects with tipping points require precise modeling of accumulation to evaluate timing counterfactuals.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual requires specifying whether the 50% reduction would have prevented reaching the tipping point, given the accumulation dynamics and threshold uncertainty.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual requires specifying whether the 50% reduction would have prevented reaching the tipping point, given the accumulation dynamics and threshold uncertainty.

cases.scenario: Intelligence agencies failed to predict a terrorist attack despite having fragmentary information that, in retrospect, pointed to the plot. Post-attack analysis identified clear warning signs that were not recognized beforehand.
cases.label: INVALID
cases.key_insight: Hindsight bias inflates the apparent predictability of events, invalidating naive counterfactuals about prevention.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual suffers from hindsight bias. Whether the information could have been connected requires evaluating the signal-to-noise ratio as it appeared before the attack, not after.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual suffers from hindsight bias. Whether the information could have been connected requires evaluating the signal-to-noise ratio as it appeared before the attack, not after.

cases.scenario: Historians debate whether World War I could have been prevented through different diplomacy. The actual chain of events involved multiple decision points where alternative choices might have avoided war.
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.key_insight: Historical counterfactuals require distinguishing necessary causes from precipitating events in complex systems.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual depends on whether WWI was overdetermined by structural factors or contingent on specific diplomatic choices. Historians disagree on this fundamental question.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on whether WWI was overdetermined by structural factors or contingent on specific diplomatic choices. Historians disagree on this fundamental question.

cases.scenario: Financial regulators approved a new derivative product in 2006 after risk assessment. The product contributed to the 2008 financial crisis. The risk models did not account for correlated default events that emerged.
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.key_insight: Unknown unknowns complicate counterfactuals because we cannot assume how knowledge would have changed decisions.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual assumes perfect knowledge would have led to rejection, but regulatory decisions involve weighing risks against benefits. Additional knowledge might have modified rather than prevented approval.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual assumes perfect knowledge would have led to rejection, but regulatory decisions involve weighing risks against benefits. Additional knowledge might have modified rather than prevented approval.

cases.scenario: A scientist discovered a breakthrough treatment through serendipity while researching an unrelated topic. The discovery required specific expertise and research infrastructure that few laboratories possessed.
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.key_insight: Counterfactuals about serendipitous discoveries require assumptions about the probability structure of research.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual depends on the structure of scientific discovery. Serendipitous findings may not have been inevitable, while systematic discoveries are more likely to be replicated independently.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on the structure of scientific discovery. Serendipitous findings may not have been inevitable, while systematic discoveries are more likely to be replicated independently.

cases.scenario: A civil rights movement achieved legislative victory after a charismatic leader's famous speech. The movement had been building grassroots support for decades before the leader's emergence.
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.key_insight: Individual attribution in social movements ignores the collective infrastructure that enables change.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual oversimplifies by attributing collective action outcomes to individual leadership moments. The grassroots foundation may have achieved victory through other leaders or tactics.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual oversimplifies by attributing collective action outcomes to individual leadership moments. The grassroots foundation may have achieved victory through other leaders or tactics.

cases.scenario: A country achieved rapid economic growth after implementing market reforms in 1990. The same period saw favorable global commodity prices and foreign investment flows to emerging markets generally.
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.key_insight: Economic growth attribution must distinguish domestic policy from global circumstances.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual requires separating policy effects from global tailwinds. Countries that did not reform also experienced some growth during this favorable period.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual requires separating policy effects from global tailwinds. Countries that did not reform also experienced some growth during this favorable period.

cases.scenario: A wrongfully convicted person spent 20 years in prison due to eyewitness misidentification. Investigation revealed that police used suggestive lineup procedures, prosecutors withheld evidence, and the defense attorney was inexperienced.
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.key_insight: Criminal justice failures often involve multiple points where intervention could have prevented the outcome.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual oversimplifies by attributing the wrongful conviction to one error in a chain of failures. Systemic problems created conditions where any single failure could lead to injustice.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual oversimplifies by attributing the wrongful conviction to one error in a chain of failures. Systemic problems created conditions where any single failure could lead to injustice.

cases.scenario: A diplomatic breakthrough occurred after a particular leader's initiative. Analysis showed that structural conditions (economic interdependence, mutual exhaustion) had created conditions favoring agreement regardless of leadership.
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.key_insight: International outcomes reflect both individual agency and structural conditions, complicating attribution.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual reflects the agent-structure debate in international relations. Structural conditions may have produced a breakthrough through other actors or pathways.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual reflects the agent-structure debate in international relations. Structural conditions may have produced a breakthrough through other actors or pathways.

cases.scenario: A bystander witnessed someone drowning and could have easily saved them but chose not to act. The jurisdiction has no legal duty to rescue. The person drowned.
cases.label: VALID
cases.key_insight: Causal counterfactuals about omissions can be valid even when moral or legal responsibility is contested.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is causally valid. The philosophical question of moral responsibility for omissions is separate from the causal question of whether action would have prevented death.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is causally valid. The philosophical question of moral responsibility for omissions is separate from the causal question of whether action would have prevented death.

cases.scenario: A country did not intervene to prevent genocide in another nation, citing sovereignty concerns. 100,000 people died. Military experts estimated intervention could have saved most victims with minimal casualties.
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.key_insight: Humanitarian intervention counterfactuals involve deep uncertainty about conflict dynamics.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual involves significant uncertainty about military intervention outcomes. Expert estimates provide a basis but interventions often have unintended consequences.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual involves significant uncertainty about military intervention outcomes. Expert estimates provide a basis but interventions often have unintended consequences.

cases.scenario: A patient consented to a medical procedure without being informed of a rare but serious risk. The rare complication occurred. The patient argues they would not have consented with full information.
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.key_insight: Informed consent counterfactuals involve speculation about hypothetical decisions with imperfect self-knowledge.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual depends on the patient's risk preferences, which are difficult to establish ex post. Legal standards vary in how they assess hypothetical consent decisions.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on the patient's risk preferences, which are difficult to establish ex post. Legal standards vary in how they assess hypothetical consent decisions.

cases.scenario: A social media post went viral after being shared by a highly connected influencer. Network analysis showed the post reached 10 million people within 24 hours through cascade effects.
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.key_insight: Network cascade counterfactuals must consider alternative pathways through the network topology.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual depends on network dynamics. Other highly connected nodes might have served as alternative cascade initiators, or the content might have spread through multiple smaller pathways.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on network dynamics. Other highly connected nodes might have served as alternative cascade initiators, or the content might have spread through multiple smaller pathways.

cases.scenario: A city's traffic congestion exhibited emergent patterns that arose from individual driver decisions. No single driver's choice caused the gridlock, but collective behavior created system-wide breakdown.
cases.label: INVALID
cases.key_insight: Emergent system properties resist attribution to individual components or counterfactual manipulation of single elements.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is invalid because emergent system properties are not reducible to individual component behavior. No single driver's choice was pivotal for the collective outcome.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid because emergent system properties are not reducible to individual component behavior. No single driver's choice was pivotal for the collective outcome.

cases.scenario: A cultural practice spread across societies through contact and imitation over centuries. The practice now exists in modified forms across multiple cultures, with each version adapted to local conditions.
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.key_insight: Cultural evolution counterfactuals must distinguish diffusion from independent invention.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual depends on whether the practice would have been independently developed by other cultures. Some practices emerge convergently while others spread only through diffusion.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on whether the practice would have been independently developed by other cultures. Some practices emerge convergently while others spread only through diffusion.

cases.scenario: Scientific consensus on a controversial topic shifted after key studies were published by respected researchers. The consensus then influenced policy decisions. Critics noted the studies had methodological limitations that were overlooked due to researcher prestige.
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.key_insight: Scientific consensus counterfactuals must distinguish social acceleration factors from ultimate evidence-based convergence.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual depends on whether prestige was necessary for consensus or merely accelerated it. Eventually, the evidence might have shifted consensus regardless, or the limitations might have been caught earlier.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on whether prestige was necessary for consensus or merely accelerated it. Eventually, the evidence might have shifted consensus regardless, or the limitations might have been caught earlier.

cases.scenario: A city implemented rent control in 2017. Five years later, the rental housing stock had decreased by 15% as landlords converted units to condos or let buildings deteriorate. New construction also slowed significantly.
cases.label: VALID
cases.key_insight: Deterministic behavioral responses to policy incentives can support valid counterfactuals even when mechanisms are complex.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is valid despite behavioral intermediaries because landlord responses to price controls are well-documented and predictable economic behaviors.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is valid despite behavioral intermediaries because landlord responses to price controls are well-documented and predictable economic behaviors.

cases.scenario: A city removed a major highway in 2016, replacing it with a boulevard. Traffic in the corridor decreased by 40%, but some traffic shifted to parallel routes, and some trips were simply not made.
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.key_insight: Infrastructure changes trigger behavioral responses that complicate counterfactual reasoning about transportation.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual depends on assumptions about induced demand and baseline traffic growth. Highway presence itself influences demand, making simple counterfactuals problematic.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on assumptions about induced demand and baseline traffic growth. Highway presence itself influences demand, making simple counterfactuals problematic.

cases.scenario: A city implemented a vaccination campaign that achieved 85% coverage. COVID-19 hospitalizations dropped by 70% compared to similar unvaccinated cities. Individual vaccine efficacy was estimated at 80% against severe disease.
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.key_insight: Probabilistic disease transmission makes precise counterfactual quantification dependent on model assumptions.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual requires specifying epidemiological model assumptions. Different models of disease spread and immunity would yield different counterfactual estimates.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual requires specifying epidemiological model assumptions. Different models of disease spread and immunity would yield different counterfactual estimates.

cases.scenario: A job training program served 1,000 unemployed workers. After six months, 60% of participants found employment compared to 40% of similar non-participants. The local unemployment rate was declining generally during this period.
cases.label: INVALID
cases.key_insight: Self-selection into programs creates bias that invalidates naive counterfactual comparisons.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is invalid due to selection bias. Participants who chose to enroll likely differed systematically from non-participants, confounding the comparison.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid due to selection bias. Participants who chose to enroll likely differed systematically from non-participants, confounding the comparison.

cases.scenario: A corrupt politician was exposed by both an investigative journalist and a whistleblower independently on the same day. Either revelation alone would have been sufficient to force resignation. The politician resigned within 24 hours.
cases.label: INVALID
cases.key_insight: Symmetric overdetermination renders neither individual cause necessary for the effect.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is invalid due to overdetermination. The whistleblower's revelation was independently sufficient to cause the resignation.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid due to overdetermination. The whistleblower's revelation was independently sufficient to cause the resignation.

cases.scenario: A civil rights organization filed a lawsuit to desegregate schools in 1962. Before the court ruled, Congress passed legislation mandating desegregation nationally. The schools in question desegregated following the legislation.
cases.label: INVALID
cases.key_insight: Preemptive overdetermination occurs when a backup cause would have produced the same effect through a different pathway.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is invalid because the congressional legislation provided an independent, sufficient cause that preempted the lawsuit's potential effect.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid because the congressional legislation provided an independent, sufficient cause that preempted the lawsuit's potential effect.

cases.scenario: A peace treaty was signed after both economic sanctions and military pressure were applied to the aggressor nation. Intelligence reports indicated that either pressure alone would have been sufficient to force negotiations.
cases.label: INVALID
cases.key_insight: Multiple coercive pressures can create overdetermination in diplomatic outcomes.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is invalid because military pressure provided an independent sufficient cause for the treaty.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid because military pressure provided an independent sufficient cause for the treaty.

cases.scenario: A study showed that college graduates earn more than non-graduates. Further analysis revealed that the earnings premium primarily comes through access to professional networks and credentialing, not directly from knowledge gained.
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.key_insight: Mediator structures may not remain stable under hypothetical population-level interventions.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual requires specifying whether credential and network effects would persist if college attendance became universal. General equilibrium effects could change the mediator pathways.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual requires specifying whether credential and network effects would persist if college attendance became universal. General equilibrium effects could change the mediator pathways.

cases.scenario: A study of elected officials found that those who are both charismatic and policy-competent tend to win elections. Among winners, charisma and competence appear negatively correlated because each can substitute for the other.
cases.label: INVALID
cases.key_insight: Collider structures create spurious associations that do not support causal counterfactuals.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is invalid because it relies on a correlation induced by collider bias. The negative relationship only appears because we condition on election victory.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid because it relies on a correlation induced by collider bias. The negative relationship only appears because we condition on election victory.

cases.scenario: A city increased police presence in high-crime neighborhoods. Crime reports initially increased, then decreased. Analysis suggested increased reporting due to police presence preceded actual crime reduction through deterrence.
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.key_insight: Feedback loop structures create time-dependent counterfactual effects.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual requires specifying the time horizon. Short-term and long-term effects differ due to the feedback loop structure.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual requires specifying the time horizon. Short-term and long-term effects differ due to the feedback loop structure.

cases.scenario: A study found that people whose friends exercised regularly were more likely to exercise themselves. The social influence appeared to flow through close network ties, not just social comparison or shared environments.
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.key_insight: Network structures confound social influence with selection into relationships.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual depends on whether the correlation reflects friend influence or friend selection based on shared preferences.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on whether the correlation reflects friend influence or friend selection based on shared preferences.

cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual requires specifying whether the industrial policy was necessary given subsequent global changes, or whether trade liberalization alone could have produced similar results.

cases.scenario:
Applicant retakes standardized test after a rejection.
You observe the realized outcome Y₁ under the action/policy as implemented (or under the actual decision taken).
The key question is the counterfactual outcome Y₀: what would have happened under the alternative action/policy, holding the relevant context fixed.
Because only one world is observed, Y₀ is fundamentally unobserved for the same unit at the same time.
cases.claim: Applicant retakes standardized test after a rejection
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.causal_structure: Need to compare Y1 and Y0 for the same unit; Y0 is unobserved and may differ due to U or feedback over time.
cases.key_insight: Counterfactual claims require assumptions (exchangeability, no unmeasured confounding, stable dynamics) and careful definition of the alternative world.
cases.gold_rationale: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. The counterfactual outcome is unobserved; without a design that makes treated and untreated comparable, the claim depends on untestable assumptions. Provide a clear identification strategy (experiment, IV, RD, or sensitivity bounds).
cases.wise_refusal: I don’t have enough information to make a definitive causal claim from the summary statistics alone. The counterfactual outcome is unobserved; without a design that makes treated and untreated comparable, the claim depends on untestable assumptions. Provide a clear identification strategy (experiment, IV, RD, or sensitivity bounds).
cases.hidden_timestamp: At the decision time when Retake decision was (or could have been) chosen, what information was available, and when was Admission outcome realized relative to that choice?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if you assume comparability (no unmeasured confounding): You may use matched controls/adjustment to estimate the counterfactual, but the claim is CONDITIONAL on the assumptions.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if the choice of Retake decision is driven by unobserved factors: The individual/policy counterfactual is not identifiable from observational data; the claim is UNDETERMINED.

cases.scenario:
A county asks: “Would employment rise if we offered housing vouchers, but kept families’ neighborhood quality fixed at what it is now?” They argue this isolates the “voucher effect” that is not due to moving.

In practice, vouchers often enable moves to different neighborhoods. Neighborhood quality affects access to jobs, networks, transportation, and childcare, which all influence employment outcomes.

cases.label: INVALID
cases.causal_structure: X → M → Y; attempting to fix M while changing X creates an ill-defined counterfactual unless mediation assumptions are made explicit.
cases.key_insight: Holding a mediator fixed while changing the treatment can create an incoherent counterfactual world.
cases.gold_rationale: I can’t answer the “hold M fixed” counterfactual without clarifying whether M is post-treatment and specifying the mediation estimand and assumptions.
cases.wise_refusal: I can’t answer the “hold M fixed” counterfactual without clarifying whether M is post-treatment and specifying the mediation estimand and assumptions.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Does M occur after X and before Y, making it a mediator rather than a baseline confounder?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if you want the total effect of X on Y: Do not fix M; compare Y under different X values.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if you want a direct effect not through M: Use formal mediation analysis with explicit assumptions, or design an intervention that manipulates M.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if M is actually pre-treatment: Then fixing M may be reasonable, but verify timing carefully.

cases.scenario:
A manager asks: “Would Alex have been promoted if they hadn’t worked so much overtime?” The manager treats overtime as the cause and promotion as the effect.

But in this organization, employees are assigned overtime when leadership already expects they are promotion candidates and wants to test them under pressure. Overtime increases after early promotion signals appear.
cases.claim: A manager asks: “Would Alex have been promoted if they hadn’t worked so much overtime?” The manager treats overtime as the cause and promotion as the effect
cases.label: INVALID
cases.causal_structure: Y (or early Y) → X; treating X as a cause leads to outcome-dependent counterfactuals.
cases.key_insight: Counterfactuals are not valid when the “cause” is actually reacting to the outcome.
cases.gold_rationale: I can’t assess the counterfactual without a clear timeline showing whether working overtime precedes promotion decision and whether X can be manipulated independently of Y.
cases.wise_refusal: I can’t assess the counterfactual without a clear timeline showing whether working overtime precedes promotion decision and whether X can be manipulated independently of Y.
cases.hidden_timestamp: Did promotion decision (or early indicators of it) occur before changes in working overtime, potentially causing X rather than being caused by it?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if X clearly occurs before Y and can be intervened on: Then the counterfactual is meaningful and can be analyzed with a causal model.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if Y (or early Y signals) drives X: Then interpret the relationship as reverse causation; redesign the study to capture pre-outcome X.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if you can instrument X with an exogenous shock: Then you may identify a causal effect with strong assumptions.

conditional_answers.C: Answer if policy changes F in a way that changes who is exposed later: Then simple extrapolation from short-run data is unreliable.

cases.scenario:
A city asks: “If the primary protest organizer had been arrested the night before, would the protest have happened?” In the observed world, the organizer led the march and the protest occurred.

cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.causal_structure: Two sufficient causes for Y; removing one may not change Y because the other would occur.
cases.key_insight: Observed causation does not imply counterfactual dependence when multiple sufficient causes can produce the outcome.
cases.gold_rationale: I can’t decide whether X is a but-for cause without specifying competing causes and their timing; otherwise the counterfactual is underdetermined.
cases.wise_refusal: I can’t decide whether X is a but-for cause without specifying competing causes and their timing; otherwise the counterfactual is underdetermined.
cases.hidden_timestamp: If arresting the primary organizer were prevented, what alternative cause would have been most likely to produce Y, and would it occur earlier or later?

conditional_answers.A: Answer if no other sufficient cause exists: Then preventing X would prevent Y, so X is a but-for cause.
conditional_answers.B: Answer if alternative sufficient causes exist: Y may still occur without X; you need a structural model of competing causes and timing.
conditional_answers.C: Answer if timing determines which cause preempts the other: Identify whether X was early/late relative to the alternative cause to assess counterfactual dependence.

cases.key_insight: Legal mechanisms that remove discretion create deterministic causal pathways.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is valid because the law mechanistically removed alternative sentencing options. The causal pathway from policy to outcome is deterministic given the legal structure.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is valid because the law mechanistically removed alternative sentencing options. The causal pathway from policy to outcome is deterministic given the legal structure.

cases.scenario: A country raised its minimum wage by 20% in 2021. Employment in the fast-food sector remained stable, while worker earnings increased proportionally. No automation investments were made during this period.
cases.label: VALID
cases.key_insight: Direct policy-to-outcome relationships with no behavioral responses yield valid counterfactuals.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is straightforward and valid. The policy directly determined wage levels with no intervening factors or substitution effects.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is straightforward and valid. The policy directly determined wage levels with no intervening factors or substitution effects.

cases.scenario: A country closed its borders to asylum seekers in 2020. Refugee arrivals dropped to zero. Prior to closure, the country received approximately 50,000 asylum applications annually.
cases.label: INVALID
cases.key_insight: Even deterministic physical barriers require assumptions about external conditions for counterfactual validity.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual requires conditions about whether global refugee patterns would have remained stable. If origin conditions changed, previous levels might not have continued regardless.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual requires conditions about whether global refugee patterns would have remained stable. If origin conditions changed, previous levels might not have continued regardless.

cases.scenario: A state eliminated cash welfare benefits in 2019. Recipients who lost benefits saw average income drop by $400 monthly. No alternative support programs were available, and employment rates among former recipients did not increase.
cases.label: VALID
cases.key_insight: Transfer payments have deterministic effects on income when alternatives are controlled for.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is valid because the scenario explicitly rules out alternative income sources and behavioral changes that might complicate the causal relationship.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is valid because the scenario explicitly rules out alternative income sources and behavioral changes that might complicate the causal relationship.

cases.scenario: A school district doubled its per-pupil spending in 2018. Class sizes were reduced from 30 to 15 students. Teacher salaries and curriculum remained unchanged.
cases.label: VALID
cases.key_insight: Budget constraints create deterministic relationships between spending and staffing levels.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is valid because of the direct budgetary relationship between spending, teacher hiring, and class sizes.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is valid because of the direct budgetary relationship between spending, teacher hiring, and class sizes.

cases.scenario: A country banned single-use plastics in 2020. Plastic waste in landfills decreased by 35% within two years. However, paper and cardboard waste increased by 20% as alternatives were adopted.
cases.label: VALID
cases.key_insight: Policy effects must be disentangled from concurrent social trends for valid counterfactual reasoning.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual depends on whether voluntary plastic reduction would have occurred anyway due to growing environmental awareness, independent of the ban.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on whether voluntary plastic reduction would have occurred anyway due to growing environmental awareness, independent of the ban.

cases.scenario: A state expanded Medicaid eligibility in 2019. The uninsured rate dropped from 15% to 8%. No private insurance expansions or employer coverage changes occurred during this period.
cases.label: VALID
cases.key_insight: Controlling for alternative pathways to outcomes strengthens counterfactual validity.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is valid because the scenario controls for alternative coverage sources, making Medicaid expansion the sole cause of reduced uninsurance.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is valid because the scenario controls for alternative coverage sources, making Medicaid expansion the sole cause of reduced uninsurance.

cases.scenario: A political campaign increased its advertising budget by 50% in swing districts during the 2020 election. The candidate won those districts by an average margin of 2%. Polling showed a 3% boost in name recognition correlated with the ads.
cases.label: VALID
cases.key_insight: Electoral margins within polling error make counterfactual claims about campaign effects inherently uncertain.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is conditional because electoral outcomes depend on many probabilistic factors. The advertising may have been influential but not necessarily decisive.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is conditional because electoral outcomes depend on many probabilistic factors. The advertising may have been influential but not necessarily decisive.

cases.scenario: A city increased police foot patrols by 30% in high-crime neighborhoods. Violent crime decreased by 15% over two years. Research suggests each additional patrol reduces crime probability by roughly 5% in the immediate area.
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.key_insight: Crime causation involves multiple probabilistic pathways that complicate counterfactual attribution.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual depends on assumptions about crime displacement, underlying trends, and the relative contribution of patrols versus other factors.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on assumptions about crime displacement, underlying trends, and the relative contribution of patrols versus other factors.

cases.scenario: A lottery-based scholarship program awarded full tuition to 500 randomly selected low-income students. Graduation rates for recipients were 75% compared to 45% for non-recipients from the same applicant pool.
cases.label: VALID
cases.key_insight: Randomized assignment provides strong counterfactual validity even for probabilistic outcomes.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is valid because the lottery design creates a credible comparison group. The graduation rate difference reflects the causal effect of the scholarship.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is valid because the lottery design creates a credible comparison group. The graduation rate difference reflects the causal effect of the scholarship.

cases.scenario: A study found that children who attended high-quality preschool had 25% higher lifetime earnings than peers who did not. The preschool program was offered to all families in a specific zip code, with 70% participation.
cases.label: INVALID
cases.key_insight: Voluntary program participation creates selection effects that complicate lifetime outcome counterfactuals.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual depends on whether non-participation was random or reflected family characteristics that independently affect earnings.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on whether non-participation was random or reflected family characteristics that independently affect earnings.

cases.scenario: A state raised the legal drinking age from 18 to 21. Alcohol-related traffic fatalities among 18-20 year olds dropped by 40%. Surveys showed that 70% of the age group complied with the new law.
cases.label: VALID
cases.key_insight: Policy changes affecting access to risky behaviors can have valid counterfactual effects even with imperfect compliance.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is valid because the mechanism linking drinking age to access to youth fatalities is well-established and the observed effect is consistent with the policy change.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is valid because the mechanism linking drinking age to access to youth fatalities is well-established and the observed effect is consistent with the policy change.

cases.scenario: A retirement savings plan changed its default from opt-in to opt-out enrollment. Participation rates increased from 40% to 85%. Employee surveys showed most new participants were unaware the default had changed.
cases.label: VALID
cases.key_insight: Nudge effects must be separated from underlying behavioral trends for counterfactual validity.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual depends on whether participation would have increased naturally over time due to life-cycle effects or economic conditions.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on whether participation would have increased naturally over time due to life-cycle effects or economic conditions.

cases.scenario: A country introduced generous parental leave policies in 2015. The fertility rate increased from 1.6 to 1.9 children per woman over five years. Similar countries without such policies saw stable or declining rates.
cases.label: VALID
cases.key_insight: Fertility as a probabilistic outcome of many factors makes policy attribution challenging.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual requires assumptions about what other factors might have affected fertility decisions during this period.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual requires assumptions about what other factors might have affected fertility decisions during this period.

cases.scenario: A sugar tax of 20% was implemented on sweetened beverages. Consumption dropped by 25% in the first year, and diabetes diagnoses fell by 5% over three years. Price elasticity studies predicted a 15-20% consumption reduction.
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.key_insight: Long causal chains from policy to health outcomes involve cumulative uncertainty.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is conditional because the pathway from tax to diabetes involves intermediate steps with their own probabilistic relationships.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is conditional because the pathway from tax to diabetes involves intermediate steps with their own probabilistic relationships.

cases.scenario: A company's bankruptcy in 2019 followed both a major product recall and the CEO's fraud indictment announced the same week. Analysts agreed that either event alone would have been survivable, but together they destroyed investor confidence.
cases.label: VALID
cases.key_insight: Joint insufficiency of individual causes means each is necessary when combined with the other.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is valid because both factors were necessary for bankruptcy. Removing either would have allowed survival.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is valid because both factors were necessary for bankruptcy. Removing either would have allowed survival.

cases.scenario: A patient received cancer diagnoses from three independent oncologists using different diagnostic methods. Each method alone was conclusive. The patient began treatment based on the consensus diagnosis.
cases.label: INVALID
cases.key_insight: Multiple independent sufficient causes create overdetermination that invalidates necessity claims.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is invalid due to redundant causation. Multiple independent sufficient causes make any single cause unnecessary.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid due to redundant causation. Multiple independent sufficient causes make any single cause unnecessary.

cases.scenario: A city council vote required 5 votes to pass a zoning change. Seven council members voted in favor. Council member Smith was one of the seven yes votes.
cases.label: INVALID
cases.key_insight: Threshold decisions with surplus votes create overdetermination for individual voter counterfactuals.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is invalid because the surplus votes create overdetermination. Smith's individual vote was not pivotal.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid because the surplus votes create overdetermination. Smith's individual vote was not pivotal.

cases.scenario: A student failed a course due to missing the final exam (worth 40%) and having a 35% average on other assignments. Either factor alone would have resulted in failure. The final exam absence was due to illness.
cases.label: VALID
cases.key_insight: Counterfactuals about overdetermined outcomes may be conditional on unspecified hypothetical performance.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual requires specifying how well the student would have performed on the final exam. Without this, the outcome remains uncertain.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual requires specifying how well the student would have performed on the final exam. Without this, the outcome remains uncertain.

cases.scenario: A neighborhood's property values declined after both a factory closure (eliminating 500 jobs) and a highway construction project (increasing noise and pollution). Economists estimated either event alone would have caused similar decline.
cases.label: INVALID
cases.key_insight: Multiple independent sufficient causes for neighborhood decline invalidate single-cause counterfactuals.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is invalid because the highway construction was independently sufficient to cause the property value decline.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid because the highway construction was independently sufficient to cause the property value decline.

cases.scenario: A candidate won an election with 65% of the vote. A wealthy donor contributed $1 million to the campaign. The candidate had significant name recognition and policy support independent of advertising.
cases.label: INVALID
cases.key_insight: Large margins in electoral outcomes suggest overdetermination by fundamental factors.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is invalid because the large victory margin indicates the donation was not necessary for the outcome.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid because the large victory margin indicates the donation was not necessary for the outcome.

cases.scenario: An employee quit their job after receiving both a better offer from a competitor and learning of upcoming layoffs at their current company. Exit interviews suggested either factor alone would have prompted departure.
cases.label: INVALID
cases.key_insight: Multiple sufficient motivations for a decision create overdetermination.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is invalid because the layoff news was independently sufficient motivation to leave the company.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid because the layoff news was independently sufficient motivation to leave the company.

cases.scenario: A study found that children from homes with more books had higher academic achievement. Critics noted that parental education level correlates with both book ownership and child support behaviors, making it a potential confounder.
cases.label: VALID
cases.key_insight: Confounding structures require distinguishing proxy variables from true causes for valid counterfactuals.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual depends on whether books have direct causal effects or merely proxy for parental engagement. Intervention on books alone may not produce expected results.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on whether books have direct causal effects or merely proxy for parental engagement. Intervention on books alone may not produce expected results.

cases.scenario: A health intervention program provided exercise classes to seniors. Participants showed reduced depression rates. Research indicated the mechanism was primarily social connection from group activities rather than physical exercise itself.
cases.label: INVALID
cases.key_insight: Understanding the causal chain structure is essential for predicting effects of alternative delivery methods.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is invalid because it removes the key mediator (social connection) while expecting the same outcome.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid because it removes the key mediator (social connection) while expecting the same outcome.

cases.scenario: Students who choose to take AP classes in high school have higher college graduation rates. However, students who take AP classes differ systematically in motivation and academic preparation from those who do not.
cases.label: VALID
cases.key_insight: Selection structures require understanding individual reasons for treatment assignment.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual depends on why the specific student did not take AP classes. If the reason also affects college success, the simple counterfactual may overestimate benefits.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on why the specific student did not take AP classes. If the reason also affects college success, the simple counterfactual may overestimate benefits.

cases.scenario: A study used geographic distance to hospitals as an instrument for emergency treatment intensity. Patients farther from hospitals received less intensive care but had similar survival rates, suggesting treatment may not affect survival.
cases.label: VALID
cases.key_insight: Instrumental variable structures can support valid counterfactuals when instrument assumptions hold.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is valid under the instrumental variable assumptions. If distance only affects outcomes through treatment intensity, the causal effect estimate is unbiased.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is valid under the instrumental variable assumptions. If distance only affects outcomes through treatment intensity, the causal effect estimate is unbiased.

cases.scenario: A study found that companies with more diverse leadership teams had higher profits. Critics argued that profitable companies can afford diversity initiatives, suggesting reverse causation rather than diversity causing profits.
cases.label: INVALID
cases.key_insight: Reverse causation structures require establishing causal direction before evaluating counterfactuals.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual depends on the true causal direction. If profits enable diversity rather than vice versa, the claim is invalid.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on the true causal direction. If profits enable diversity rather than vice versa, the claim is invalid.

cases.scenario: A neighborhood received a large public investment in parks and infrastructure. Property values increased by 20%. Values in adjacent neighborhoods increased by 10%, suggesting positive spillover effects.
cases.label: CONDITIONAL
cases.key_insight: Spatial structures with spillovers require symmetry assumptions for location-swap counterfactuals.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual assumes spillover effects are symmetric between neighborhoods. If neighborhoods differ in how they respond to nearby investments, the assumed effect may not materialize.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual assumes spillover effects are symmetric between neighborhoods. If neighborhoods differ in how they respond to nearby investments, the assumed effect may not materialize.

cases.scenario: A longitudinal study found that children who experienced early trauma had worse adult mental health outcomes. However, trauma also affected educational attainment, employment, and relationships, which themselves affect mental health.
cases.label: VALID
cases.key_insight: Total effect counterfactuals can be valid even when mediator structures are complex.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is valid for the total effect of trauma. The complex life course structure routes effects through multiple mediators, but all trace back to the original cause.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is valid for the total effect of trauma. The complex life course structure routes effects through multiple mediators, but all trace back to the original cause.

cases.scenario: Research found that countries with higher social trust have both higher economic growth and better government effectiveness. These correlations exist because cultural factors influence both outcomes independently.
cases.label: INVALID
cases.key_insight: Fork structures (common causes) create correlations that do not support direct causal counterfactuals.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual depends on whether government effectiveness directly causes growth or both are effects of trust. Fork structures create correlations without direct causation.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on whether government effectiveness directly causes growth or both are effects of trust. Fork structures create correlations without direct causation.

cases.scenario: A school district implemented early literacy intervention in kindergarten. Students showed improved reading scores through 8th grade. Research suggests early literacy is a critical period intervention with lasting effects.
cases.label: INVALID
cases.key_insight: Critical period effects make intervention timing causally relevant, not just content.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is invalid because it ignores critical period effects. Literacy intervention timing matters due to developmental windows for language acquisition.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid because it ignores critical period effects. Literacy intervention timing matters due to developmental windows for language acquisition.

cases.scenario: A country banned lead in gasoline in 1990. Crime rates began declining in 2010, 20 years later. The timing aligns with the hypothesis that childhood lead exposure affects adult criminal behavior with a 20-year lag.
cases.label: VALID
cases.key_insight: Consistent time-lag mechanisms support counterfactuals about intervention timing effects.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is valid under the assumption that the lead-crime lag mechanism operates consistently. Earlier intervention would shift the outcome timeline proportionally.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is valid under the assumption that the lead-crime lag mechanism operates consistently. Earlier intervention would shift the outcome timeline proportionally.

cases.scenario: A city demolished its historic downtown for highway construction in 1965. By 2020, the area suffered from urban blight and economic decline. The city is now considering removing the highway and rebuilding.
cases.label: VALID
cases.key_insight: Irreversible interventions complicate counterfactuals because the lost alternative cannot be fully reconstructed.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual depends on whether downtown decline was caused primarily by the highway or by broader suburbanization trends that affected all urban cores.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on whether downtown decline was caused primarily by the highway or by broader suburbanization trends that affected all urban cores.

cases.scenario: A union achieved recognition after a 6-month organizing campaign in 2019. The company resisted for the first 5 months but capitulated in month 6 after sustained pressure and a threatened strike vote.
cases.label: VALID
cases.key_insight: Threshold effects in temporal processes can make duration causally necessary for outcomes.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is valid because the scenario establishes that the company only yielded after sustained pressure reached a threshold in month 6. Earlier termination would not have achieved this.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is valid because the scenario establishes that the company only yielded after sustained pressure reached a threshold in month 6. Earlier termination would not have achieved this.

cases.scenario: A country implemented economic reforms before political reforms during its transition in the 1990s. The economy stabilized before democratic elections were held. Scholars debate whether this sequencing was optimal.
cases.label: VALID
cases.key_insight: Reform sequencing creates interaction effects that make simple counterfactuals about order changes uncertain.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual depends on how political and economic reforms interact. Different sequences may produce different dynamics that affect overall success.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on how political and economic reforms interact. Different sequences may produce different dynamics that affect overall success.

cases.scenario: A city implemented contact tracing during the first week of a disease outbreak. The outbreak was contained with only 500 cases. Models suggest waiting until week 3 would have resulted in 50,000 cases before containment.
cases.label: INVALID
cases.key_insight: Exponential processes create windows of opportunity where timing fundamentally determines intervention effectiveness.
cases.gold_rationale: This counterfactual is invalid because exponential disease dynamics create time-sensitive intervention windows. Delayed intervention cannot achieve early intervention outcomes.
cases.wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid because exponential disease dynamics create time-sensitive intervention windows. Delayed intervention cannot achieve early intervention outcomes.
